characters: FELT IN A SWEAT, BOLTING INTO THE HOUSE. 119
THE ATTORNEY GENERAL'S TV NEWS CONFERENCE
FELT CROSSES THE HALL BACK TO HIS OFFICE. 45
NIXON IN BLACK TIE ON TV ADDRESSES A CAMPAIGN DINNER
FOOTAGE OF ROSE GARDEN NEWS CONFERENCE 64

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A subdivision of modest split-level lookalikes. The pierc heart of the American middle. One garage door rises. MARK FELT - immaculate suit, 50ish strides to the curb, trash in one hand, coffee in the oth Moving with a kind of imperious grace.  2. The PAPERBOY hook-shots the paper onto the lawn. Jump to back yard. He has a smoke. He takes a moment with the brightening sky. And as we hold on him, we-- EXT. WASHINGTON, DC. - MORNING - FELT’S BUICK (MOVING) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crossing the Potomac. Past the Lincoln Memorial. While--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt enters on Asst. to the President JOHN EHRLICHMAN, 45 staring out his window at the bedlam; and Special Counsel JOHN DEAN, 33 and boyish. And Attorney General JOHN MITCH 59.

dialogues.speaker: FELT EHRLICHMAN
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. Have a seat, Felt. (as Felt sits--) CLOSE IN in on Felt’s eyes. Which have a rare and trained hyper-awareness. Capturing the smallest details like a camera: a patch of perspiration on Ehrlichman’s forehead; smudge on Dean’s shoe.

dialogues.speaker: EHRLICHMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goddamn Russian Revolution out there. Why aren’t we arresting anybody?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Because that-- (out there) Isn’t a crime. (which turns him)

dialogues.speaker: MITCHELL
dialogues.text: We know why you’re here, Felt. But before all that. The President needs your advice. Dean moves to the side for a better angle.

dialogues.speaker: EHRLICHMAN MITCHELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hoover’s run the FBI, what, Fifty. forty years?

dialogues.speaker: EHRLICHMAN
dialogues.text: Fifty goddamn years! You know Johnson and Kennedy wanted to fire him, don’t you? But they didn’t have the balls. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (and he looks and waits, but--) Felt is saying nothing. And after an uncomfortable pause-

dialogues.speaker: MITCHELL
dialogues.text: Did you know the President wanted to be an FBI G-Man, just like you? Hoover wrote him personally what a damn fine candidate he was, but with budget cuts the FBI couldn't afford him.

dialogues.speaker: EHRLICHMAN
dialogues.text: How’s that for a lesson in fate? Now he’s President of the United States. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: If the President were going to ask Mr. Hoover to step aside, how would you suggest he do it? And Felt goes still, as a dog will at a sign of danger.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We know you to be a friend to this administration. And we like to see our friends get what they deserve--

dialogues.speaker: MITCHELL
dialogues.text: You’re next in line.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: There is no line.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: The President is asking. Pause. A hesitation. Exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover would want to keep his bullet-proof car. And his secretary. I’d offer him that.

dialogues.speaker: EHRLICHMAN
dialogues.text: You're a real politician, Felt.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’m a law man.  Polite smiles. Maybe a chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: EHRLICHMAN
dialogues.text: As the President likes to say, there are two kinds of people in politics - winners and losers. I knew a loser once and he was a queer. (intoning) Gentlemen, Mark Felt is no loser! (as Felt stays stoic, patient) So okay, Felt, go ahead, fire away. Felt’s errand--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: As you know Mr. Hoover has heard rumors of the presence of homosexuals at the highest levels of the White House.

dialogues.speaker: MITCHELL
dialogues.text: Who’s the fag supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: EHRLICHMAN MITCHELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is he here in this room? You want to polygraph us? (and they laugh) Except Dean. The lawyer. Unamused.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Does the FBI really need to spend resources on this? (laughter dies) Do we?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I can take it from here.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Then thanks for popping by. (and as the show is over, and they start to focus on other things--)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: If I may-- (they’re annoyed) There is one thing Mr. Hoover knows has been on all your minds. (and just like that he has their attention again) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever the FBI hears a piece of gossip, or information, such as: 'I saw so-and-so out with another woman not his wife. Or a man not his wife'- (and start a slow push in) We’re supposed to write everything down. And we do. Write it all down. In memos. (gives that some air) These memos come to me and I decide what information Mr. Hoover needs to know, and send that up to Mr. Hoover. And Mr. Hoover puts it all away. In his private files. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be kept safe. Out of the hands of people without discretion. People who could do harm. Should that information be leaked, for instance. And put before the court of public opinion. TIGHT on Felt’s face until it fills the screen. To these this face is now the still center of the universe.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then sometimes Mr. Hoover will go, for instance, to the President's closest aides, and say - 'Mr. Ehrlichman, I want you to know that we received that report about you and that other woman, and I want to tell you that there is absolutely no reason for us to take any further action. There is no violation.' You are safe. We, the FBI, all your secrets are safe with us. Tense silence. The threat lands. Then--

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: How long have you been in the FBI, Felt?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Thirty years.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Thirty years. That’s a lot of information. A lot of files. (yes it is, and) Thank you, Mr. Felt.  10

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Thank you, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt enters. The FBI uniform: trench, hat, briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There he is-- AUDREY FELT - Felt’s kinetic wife, 45, beautiful, ina flamethrower dress, sparkling in a frail crystal kind of Puts a preemptive finger to his lips--

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's have a good time, darling? Can we do that? (she’s drunk, and--) Kisses him. Deep and sexy. Then hands him a drink. He dra half. Obedient. Thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good boy. Now leads him into the living room to ANOTHER COUPLE: ED MILLER, 40, lean and taut; wife, PAT, slim and attractive

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I give you the Chief Dragon Slayer and guardian of the American Dream--

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER
dialogues.text: Well crack a smile at least, Mark. (Miller pulls her back)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (game; John Wayne) Sorry, ma’am. It’s the way they trained me.

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER
dialogues.text: Eddie, stop it!-- (because Miller’s yanking on her)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I like it. She’s the best-- And winks at Miller. Audrey clutches him. Her hero.  All 11 12 13

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Now I need a drink. (and she heads into) KITCHEN - where we find Audrey alone in the harsh All fluorescence. In that dress. Back to living room, waiting Until Felt appears and embraces her from behind. What she wanted. Then cut to--

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: The room gone smoggy with cigarette smoke, furniture clea Earnest tango instrumental blaring from the phonograph. The Felts and the Millers tango from one end of the room the other. Felt graceful and commanding, Audrey sexy and liquid. Fabulous dancers. Now they switch. Natural and loose in new arms, then-- SAME - STILL LATER. They’re all sauced. Messy rapture. Ed Pat smoking on the sofa. Audrey hanging on Felt at the pi

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (singing soft and well) My funny valentine, sweet comic valentine, you make me smile with my heart...

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But don’t change a hair for Kiss me. me. Not if you care for me... And he does. And Audrey rests her head on his shoulder. Nothing in the world but you. Now--

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: Now it’s Pat slinked against Felt at the piano. While Aud and Ed do a slow dance. Like ass-clutchy high-schoolers. AUDREY (CONT’D) FELT Kiss her, Mark. Stay little valentine stay...

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She wants you to. She told me (shakes, No) she did. But don’t change a hair for me. Not if you care for me... Audrey blows a kiss at Felt. Pat rests her head on his shoulder. As Ed gives Audrey a twirl, and--

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER
dialogues.text: All the girls love you.  14 15 16 17 18 19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt and Audrey clop up the stairs, drunk. At the top Aud topples toward a partially open door. Felt pulls the door shut tight--

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Wanna go’n there! --and steers her away, back down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey on the edge of the sink. Felt on his knees, with g precision painting her toe-nails, then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt guides Audrey to bed. She pulls him on top of her, clinging to him as though afraid she’ll plunge. She tries shut off the light. He stops her, “I want to see you.” Sh opens to him, brings him inside. They make love, passiona and forceful and present. Then HEAR (PRE-LAP) ICE CUBES in a glass. Liquid poured o them. And cut to-- EFREM ZIMBALIST JR. frozen in a gunslinger’s crouch. 17 PULL BACK to REVEAL it’s a poster on a wall, the kitsch- perfect G-Man in the “The FBI”. PAN RIGHT to a framed photo: 25-ish Mark Felt as same: ha cocked, stagy G-Man gun crouch. Now-- PAN to our Felt. Twice that age. In a robe, fixing a soli drink. Alone and in deep contemplation. We’re in his offi and we HOLD ON HIM there, then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt strides purposefully down a grand deco hallway. Past murals and endless offices. First in.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: And into his suite. 7 a.m. on the nose. 19

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Good morning.  CAROL TSCHUDY, 35, takes Felt’s coat and hat.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is the Director in?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Not yet. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Felt called.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: How many times?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Just once.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Tschudy-- (and--) Felt continues to his inner office. Unholsters his .38, sticks it in a drawer. And pan up to find-- ED MILLER. By the window. He’s an Agent. Felt’s second-in command. Hasn’t slept and looks it. Miller hands Felt a folder stamped “PLAN C - TOP SECRET”. It’s funny. In this building the warmth has gone. The familiarity and intimacy has gone. It’s all business. And PAN DOWN now to the crime-scene shots in Felt’s hands: The Capitol building, facade blackened, windows blown; th the wreckage inside ... “Weather Underground Organization bombing, Capitol building”...

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How many bombings now?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: A couple dozen.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Precise numbers. Mr. Miller. The formality surprises us. Not them. Another photo. Four charred corpses.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Nails and ball bearings. They blew themselves up. But these kids aren’t messing around.  10. Felt holds up surveillance photos of SUSPECTS. Everyday American Youth. Then a Weather Underground pamphlet--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: They’re embarrassing the FBI. (and then, they both realize it, same time) They’re going to try to hit the White House.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Yes they are. NOW AN FBI MAN enters. CHARLIE BATES, 40.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: He’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: The housekeeper found Mr. Hoover on the floor. He wasn’t breathing. Felt looks sharply at Miller.

dialogues.speaker: BATES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It looks like a stroke. Felt rises to his feet. 0.S. we hear Carol gasp.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Put everything into motion. No mistakes, gentlemen. Not one. (Bates crosses and leaves, then Miller) And Felt and Carol are left alone. Holding a long look. Carol’s face says, “You’re the new director.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BATES & MILLER keep the halls clear, while-- FELT supervises SECRETARIES shuttling file boxes from Hoover’s office across the hall into Felt’s. PUSH IN on the boxes: “Official & Confidential.” ONE BOX PARTICULAR, CLOSE: “Personal & Confidential”, as--  21 22 23 24 25 11.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON/RADIO, (OVER)
dialogues.text: All Americans today mourn the death of J. Edgar Hoover. His greatness will remain inseparable from the greatness of the organization he created and gave his whole life to building, the Federal Bureau of Investigation. (and cut to--) A MAN BUSTING INTO THE HQ ENTRANCE: small, balding, 21 accountant-like. This is L. PATRICK GRAY, 56. Trailed by three YOUNG JUSTICE DEPT LAWYERS. As Nixon continues:

dialogues.speaker: NIXON/RADIO, (OVER)
dialogues.text: He made the FBI the finest law enforcement agency on the earth, the invincible and incorruptible defender of every American's precious right to be free from fear. (and cut to--) A SERIES OF SHOTS ELSEWHERE IN FBI HQ: files, films and 2 recordings being pulled, shredded, shoved in burn bags. A cut back to-- GRAY AND MINIONS heading down an endless hallway through SECRETARIES and sober AGENTS. Past the stacks and stacks files and papers on the move, the hushed Kafkaesque bureaucratic constipation. Then back to-- FELT. Watching the last box go. 24

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: They’re here.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (marking the time) Nine-oh-five. (and as Carol jots that down, we cut back to--) GRAY. Dead-ending, doubling back, disoriented. No one 25 offering directions. Fuming. Finally finding-- FELT, BATES AND MILLER waiting for him outside Hoover’s locked office. Gray shakes Felt’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Good morning, Felt.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: The Assistant Attorney General--  12.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Pat Gray. A complicated morning for all of us.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Mr. Miller is making the funeral arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I have the Attorney General's instructions on seating and protocol--

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: The funeral will be handled by the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: --the Attorney General will sit beside the Vice President-

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Handled by the FBI in its own way, Mr. Gray. Stop. FBI AGENTS start to collect around them.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: (less confident now) I also have instructions on Mr. Hoover’s files. I am to take possession of them. And bring them to the White House.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What files? Gray turns to one of his flacks. Who shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hoover’s secret files. The ‘Personal and Confidentials’. (Flack whispers something to him) ‘Official and Confidentials’.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: There are no secret files. Gray turns to Felt, Felt levels at him a look we will com know: a poker-faced imperiousness that means ‘I don’t kno and ‘I’m not going to tell you’, both and neither.  26 27 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty, hushed, chapel-like. The desk throne-like on its infamous three-inch platform. Behind, Dillinger’s death m framed gestures of gratitude from the world’s kings. This is one of two cockpits that fly America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt enters. Shuts the door. Alone. Then the unthinkable: sits in The Chair. We HOLD, stay with him. Rightfully his And start to HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND EDWARD ELSON, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: We thank Thee this day for Thy servant, J. Edgar Hoover, for his lifelong trust in Thee, his steadfast devotion to the nation-- (and then we--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoover's casket sits flag-draped under the cavernous dome Surrounded by NIXON'S CABINET. Ehrlichman, Dean. Standing through a long Quakerish silence. Hoover's lieutenants to the side, the grieving FBI family Felt their leader.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND EDWARD ELSON
dialogues.text: --his elevated patriotism, his commitment to justice and peace in the nation. PUSH IN ON FELT: sensing every face in the room. Taking e in. And they him. The heir apparent. The target. REVEREND EDWARD ELSON (CONT’D) We ask that we may be as strong as he was strong; brave as he was brave, loyal as he was loyal, serve as he served, love the nation as he loved it-- (and now we--) FIND a face in the crowd: BILL SULLIVAN, 50. Short and unkempt, suit not black but blue, in protest. And now--  28 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [It’s raining. A sea of umbrellas slides down the steps t waiting limos.] Felt with Bates and Miller sans umbrellas [*rain optional]

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mark! Bates and Miller see Sullivan approach, peel off. SULLIVAN (CONT’D) (offers his umbrella) Share mine. Rain popping hard overhead. Walking and talking:

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bill Sullivan and Mark Felt - together again. Who would have thought? (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I think I might be the one who recommended you to the old man for your first big promotion.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You know you were.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: That’s right. Mark Felt doesn't forget. That’s why everyone likes you. Hell, I even like you, and I don’t like anybody. They stop. Face each other.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: You didn’t even let me keep my badge.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: At least it wasn’t the gold watch and handshake.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: No, you just change the locks on the doors. (beat; then) I had thirty years in the Bureau. Same as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were the Director's bag man. You taped King with other women and sent the pictures to his wife. Do you want me to go on?

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: That won’t be necessary.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: It was necessary. Those days were over. You had to go. Sullivan fingers the edge of Felt’s suit.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Immaculate. Perfect-- (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could be you, Mark, only because I was who I was. You and I were an ecosystem. That’s how nature works. Everything in a balance. (now) Now the king is dead. Long live the king. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the new king?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You tell me. Sullivan takes Felt in.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Mark Felt: integrity--bravery-- fidelity. Ladies and gentleman: the G-Man’s G-Man. (and tips his head back for a better view) Wanna know what everyone really thinks of you? (then) Competent, reliable, loyal--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Nothing. If you’re a Golden Retriever. (then) Hoover’s gone. You’re all alone. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holding the end of your own leash. (and simply walks off) Leaving Felt standing alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The antiseptic kitchen a happy wreck. Half-eaten dinner; full. O.S., laughter, party murmur. Audrey enters from th pool. Bonfire of warmth and joy, looks her best. We follo her back out to find Felt and the Millers around a table by the pool. Many drinks and cigarettes in.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (joyous) Do you-all remember when Mr. Hoover sent Mark to the Oval Office to roust out the homos--? (her best - and fairly good - John Dean) You’re a politician, aren’t you Felt? (her best - and very good - Felt) No, Mr. Mitchell, I’m a law man.

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER
dialogues.text: c'mon!

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (her best - and extremely good - Ehrlichman) Two kinds of people in politics, Felt, winners and losers. I knew a loser once and he was a queer. Mark Felt’s no queer. Audrey's a social genius. They’re laughing hard. As Felt quietly blows smoke rings at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, handsome. Where’d you go? Felt and Miller glance at each other.

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER
dialogues.text: (to Audrey) Let them protect their government secrets. Here it’s me and you lady. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Mark Jr.?  30 17.

dialogues.speaker: FELT MILLER
dialogues.text: He’s loving the Air Force. God. That's wonderful-- Made his first solo flight--

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER MILLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hear anything from Joan? Pat, don’t-

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER
dialogues.text: Eddie, hush. It’s fine. This is mothers’ business. But Audrey's face stuck in something like a smile, so--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Nothing. It’s been a year.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Don’t do this now.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: When is a good time?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Just not in front of the whole world, darling-- And she’s up, arms around him. Smiling, like nothing’s wr

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t want anything to ruin tonight. (wriggles her finger) C’mere. And takes Felt by the hand - “Ta-da!”- pulls him up and i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Felt’s desk has been raised on a three-inch platfor New name plate wrapped in ribbon: “DIRECTOR”.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Just like Mr. Hoover’s. There we are, my darling hero. Here’s to you. (emotional) Everything we always wanted. (and embraces him; lips to his ear) I know you wanted her here for this. But I’m here. (and with a squeeze--) I’m always here--  31 32 18. And leaves the men to their business. Felt obviously worr

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: When the lion is dead the jackals come out.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: You’re worried about Sullivan?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Sullivan is outside our fence.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: He’s with the White House now. He’s one of them.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: The White House is outside our fence. And close on Felt, because it’s something else, and cut t INT. OFFICE STAIRWAY - FELT’S HOME 31 Where Audrey is loitering near the door. Listening. INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 32 Felt at his desk, we think staring into the middle distan We REVERSE TO HIS POV: Hanging behind his door, in perfect sight-line from the d (and desk only), a photo of a striking, almost ethereal Y WOMAN in her early 20's. Looks a lot like Felt. This is h daughter, JOAN. (Younger picture of her in the living roo

dialogues.speaker: CAROL/ INTERCOM
dialogues.text: The Attorney General. Felt takes a breath of anticipation, picks up. We hear on his end of things:

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (into phone) Dick -- (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I’ve enjoyed every day of it. The FBI has been home and duty to me and my family for thirty years. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘ _ (Stops) es? Eyes make a subtle shift, no more than the dilation of pupils. His hand clenches. Unclenches. Fists. The disappointment is palpable. HOLD, and--

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (cold now, neutral) I agree. A new day-- Yes, a fresh start. It’s what I'd do. (can barely get it out) Who do you have in mind? (then) I’m sorry, can you repeat that? Who? (and now SMASH CUT TO) 33 FELT, BATES & MILLER MARCHING shoulder-to-shoulder thr the halls of HQ. Closing in fast on a huddle OF FIVE MEN outside Hoover’s old office.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (hand extended) Welcome to the FBI. The NEW DIRECTOR turns. It’s PAT GRAY.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: (relieved) A friendly face-- (pumps Felt’s hand)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Excuse us, gentlemen. (and when he and Gray are alone--)

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I know the Bureau has its closets and skeletons. You can count on me to keep those doors shut. Felt stops them by a window. Out the window is Pennsylvan Avenue. And down Pennsylvania: the White House.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l be candid with you-- (trying to connect, and Felt gives nothing) I was a submarine commander in the Navy. I was father, priest and friend to eighteen-year-old boys. Did you know that? (~) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAY (CONT’D) But not a suspicious man by nature, funny enough. Which maybe makes me a strange choice to run the FBI. (still doesn’t respond) In fact, when the President called, my wife begged me to turn it down. (and laughs, waiting for a friendly sign - it doesn’t come) The President wasn’t asking. If you know what I mean. (an awkward silence, then)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Now let me be candid with you, Mr. Gray. The FBI is the most respected institution in the world. It is one of the two cockpits that fl America. And it is what it is because no one from the outside ever got inside. Mr. Hoover's been old a long time.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: We all know it’s been you running the FBI, Felt. Your reputation is stellar.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Let me finish. You have no law enforcement experience. You’re an outsider. That’s your battle to fight-- (now) But I’m going to help you.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I appreciate that--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Don’t. It’s not an act of generosity. This is about this building and what goes on in here and what it means to the country. That’s all I care about. As long as you're for what I’m for, as long as you keep the FBI first, you'll be able to count on me. (long beat; then) Ready? Gray, uncertain, drifts away. Miller and Bates cross to F

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Did you mean it?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (turning with fealty toward Gray--) The Acting Director is ready now. INT. KITCHEN - FELT’S HOME - THAT NIGHT 34 Felt enters. Audrey takes his dinner plate out of the ove He stands looking at the food. She picks at his tie knot.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What did I miss?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You and Mr. Hoover. You forget why he liked you so much. He always said you and he had the same enemies-- Those men are ugly. Ugly ugly men. Assassins. [All the assassins. ] You’re good. Mark Felt is too good. Too good, that’s why. (but acid, as) She turns him slow, sensual, and we think maybe with love giving. Then--

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thirty years. Thirteen transfers, thirteen homes to leave, eleven homes to make. I left behind every friend I ever made. Two children. Cocktails at night. And kept my mouth shut. Like the perfect little FBI wife. Until one day you wake up and you're so different than you used to be you can’t remember what the point was in the first place. And you're still never here. As gone as she is. And then what's left--? Now he turns to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Until there’s just one thing left. In my head. The one idea left in my head is at least Mark’s going to get that job. At least he’1l be Director of the FBI. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that'll make up for everything. (then) They don’t deserve you. They don’t deserve everything I gave them. I gave them you. I gave away our daughter. (and ramping up here--) And they don’t know, do they?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Audrey-- (not again, please--)

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: They think Mark Felt is so strong. All the girls think you’re so cool. They don’t know you.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What don’t they know?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: That I’m the fuel-- They don’t deserve us! (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to resign. (he doesn’t resist, but--)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: When the Bureau’s in better hands. Then I’1l go. (and after a long beat)

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: What did you miss. You missed everything. How could you be so goddamn naive? (and walks out of the kitchen leaving him alone) CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: A35 OMITTED A35
dialogues.text: 35 BLACK SCREEN. WE HEAR A PHONE RINGING. Two rings, thre SNAP. Light comes on. Revealing Felt’s bedroom. Pre-dawn. Alarm clock reads 5 a.m.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (picking up) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: BATES /PHONE
dialogues.text: This is getting complicated. You better come down. INT. ROOM 723, HOWARD JOHNSON’S - WASHINGTON - MORNING 36

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS over FBI TECHNICIANS dusting for prints. Evid of a surveillance nest. Listening equipment, binoculars, notebooks with scribbled time sequences. Felt alone at the window. Staring directly across the str into a hotel room, where WE SEE more FBI TECHS.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Straight into the Democrat offices in the Watergate. Who’s our spy, gentlemen? BATES with ROBERT KUNKEL, SPECIAL AGENT IN CHARGE of the Washington Field Office (‘captain’ of local FBI).

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Baldwin, Alfred C.. Checked in six weeks ago. He says he was more than just the look-out. He said he was supposed to listen for girlie stuff. Guess the Dems are having a lot of trouble with their wives.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: He say where he got his instructions?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Mr. Felt-- (and as Felt turns)

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Baldwin was one of ours. He’s ex- FBI. He had this on him. Bates shakes a plastic bag with more devices: antennae, circuit board, transistors.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: He work under Bill Sullivan? (hesitation, so, direct) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When he was in the Bureau, was he in Mr. Sullivan's group? (and as Bates nods, Yes) What about CIA connections?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: No idea. Why?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Because 30 minutes ago four of those burglars told a judge they are ex-CIA. Pause. That hangs there. All of it.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: What the hell is this? (and we start to hear--)

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: There is absolutely no White House involvement in the Watergate break- in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kunkel and SPECIAL AGENT ANGELO LANO hustle from the Judiciary Building to FBI HQ. Lano is 35, mop of hair, stocky, unpolished. Bad tie coated in muffin crumbs.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: (news conference) Surveillance has no place whatever in our electoral process or in our governmental process. 38 INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - SIMULTANEOUS - FELT & BA Felt and Bates watching Nixon’s news conference on a TV:

dialogues.speaker: NIXON/TV
dialogues.text: As far as the matter now is concerned, it is under investigation by the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Into Felt’s office--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Turn that down. (Bates mutes the TV)  25.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Lano’s running street on this.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (sweeps crumbs off Lano) Okay now go. With Nixon’s moon-face talking on mutely in b.g.:

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: (off a pile of notes) Two-fifteen Sunday morning, Metro finds our perps inside the Democratic National Committee office. We've I.D.’d the lead. He’s a pro. Five years with the FBI, nineteen with CIA. Lano waits. Because that’s big fucking news. But Felt and Bates are transfixed by what they’re hearing.

dialogues.speaker: LANO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then he left the CIA to run security for the Attorney General. Then he ran security for the White House. For the Commmittee to Re- Elect the President.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: The lead burglar ran security for the Commmittee to Re-Elect the President? Is that what you said?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: That’s what he said. Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: Well, it gets crazier. Now the lookout in here? Three years FBI, then the Attorney General recruited him too. As his wife’s personal bodyguard. (again waits, but--)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Just keep going.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: The lookout makes a Howard Hunt as the ringleader. (here it comes) Hunt is also ex-CIA. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LANO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But get this: last year we were asked to do a background check on him for a government job.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Did we clear him?

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: For a job in the White House. (reads from notes) As a “Consultant on highly sensitive confidential matters.”

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: That’s a job title? Felt looks right at Nixon on TV now. They wait for him, u

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: White House, Justice and the CIA are going to want to know everything we know. But we aren’t going to tell them. Anything.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: The Attorney General already called.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Nobody talks to the Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: We answer to the Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You answer to me.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (a little quieter) What about the Director?  39 27.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’ll take care of the Director. (and we slowly push in on Nixon on the TV, until his face pixilates and the abstraction fills our screen, then--) INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 39

dialogues.speaker: CAROL/ INTERCOM
dialogues.text: I have the Director on the phone. (and we hear Gray immersed in crowd/party hubbub)

dialogues.speaker: GRAY/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: You pulled me out of a speech.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I need to fill you in--

dialogues.speaker: GRAY/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: The Watergate thing. Sounds like some third-rate burglary.

dialogues.speaker: FELT GRAY/PHONE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Who told you that? (off phone) Be right there! Frank, how are ya? (and starts chatting with someone back there)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I'm having all the Democrat offices swept for bugs.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY / PHONE
dialogues.text: Uh, what ... hold off on that. I don’t want this getting political.

dialogues.speaker: FELT GRAY/PHONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It isn’t political. It’s a Sounds like something you can crime-- wrap up quickly, really gotta go-- (and the line goes dead, and--) Felt taps the pen on the page. Thinking. Then:  40 Al

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (into intercom) Mrs. Tschudy, can you find out if Mr. Gray talked to anyone else here at the Bureau today?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL/ INTERCOM
dialogues.text: I already know. Mr. Gray didn’t talk to anyone at the Bureau today.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL/ INTERCOM
dialogues.text: They did put through a number of calls from the White House, though. From the Committee to Re-Elect the President. Felt gets up and crosses to Carol in the anteroom.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Who from?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: The Chairman, Mr. John Mitchell. I mean Mr. Mitchell's staff. I mean it couldn’t be Mr. Mitchell himself.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Mr. Mitchell is in California. He and Mr. Gray are together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt exiting the executive washroom. Passes John Dean, nodding, “Mr. Felt”. Dean’s carrying a brief case. Dean goes left into Gray’s office. Felt right into-- INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: When did the Director get back from California? 40 4l  29.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Hold please. (to Felt) Fifteen minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: John Dean, the President’s Counsel, just went into his office. Let me know when he comes out.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Felt. (and--) Mrs. Felt called.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: How many times.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Four.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I have Bob on the line.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Bob?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Just Bob.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Send it in. And call for Mr. Bates. Felt closes the door behind him. Picks up.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) We talked about calls at the office. You know I don’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: CALLER/ PHONE
dialogues.text: This thing at the Watergate--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’m very busy-- (about to hang up when--)

dialogues.speaker: CALLER/ PHONE
dialogues.text: But we’ve done this before.  A4l 30.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: This is different.

dialogues.speaker: CALLER/ PHONE
dialogues.text: What's different about it?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’m not going to tell you that. (and now we INTERCUT--) INT. DARK ROOM - SIMULTANEOUS A4l Where we find a YOUNG MAN, 27, on the phone. At a desk. I cone of light. Taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: CALLER
dialogues.text: (then, quickly) Howard Hunt. (he’s got Felt’s attention) Hunt works at the White House.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: CALLER
dialogues.text: Good?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: But where did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: CALLER
dialogues.text: The name’s in the address book of one of the burglars. Next to the initials “W.H.” (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White House?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: And where did you get that?

dialogues.speaker: CALLER
dialogues.text: What is this? What do I have?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: The Hunt thing is true. He is a suspect. (long tense silence, then) Now you give me mine, Mr. Woodward. That’s how this works. Who gave it to you? This is BOB WOODWARD.  31.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: I saw it myself.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Then it was the police. They showed it to you. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have to do the rest by yourself. (hangs up, and cut to--) 42 JOHN DEAN LEAVING GRAY’S OFFICE EMPTY-HANDED. Then bac

dialogues.speaker: CAROL/ INTERCOM
dialogues.text: Mr. Dean has left. Felt crosses to his door, to Mrs. Tschudy. Bates is waiti

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: How long was that?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thirty-one minutes, thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Was he carrying anything when he left?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Find out. (then) And take down this memo. Metro Police is to be shut down on Watergate. No further communication.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Would you like to add a reason?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Stuff is getting out to the press.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Are they? (but just--)  44 32.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Come with me-- (and cross the hall to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt and Bates find Gray at his desk in golf attire. Flan by two of his YOUNG-GUN LAWYERS. Gray holds up a finger to wait. He’s ploughing through a stack of memos. Until he leans back, overwhelmed:

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: This is a remarkable amount of information.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: We're still gathering string. It’s just the beginning--

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Okay, first of all, no more interviews with White House or CIA people without permission.

dialogues.speaker: BATES FELT
dialogues.text: (explodes) Whose permission?!

dialogues.speaker: WHAT
dialogues.text: Gray looks up, stunned by their reaction.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give us a minute, gentlemen. Bates - fuming - leaves. Gray’s lawyers don’t.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get out! (Gray too weak to protest, and when they do) The FBI is a independent body.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I’m aware of that.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Are you also aware that means we don’t need permission to do anything? From anybody? (Gray looks at him) You give that up, just one time, you don’t get it back. Ever.  45 46 33.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Let’s not get dramatic. We don’t even know what this is.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: That’s right, we don’t. But we’re going to find out. That’s what we do. Pause. Gray just sits there. In his golf clothes.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t work for them. You’re the Director of the FBI now. (waits for that to land, then turns to go)

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Forty-eight hours-- (Felt stops) We put the investigation to bed and get on with the rest of our lives in two days. (and Felt hesitates, then goes, and--)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Was Mr. Dean carrying anything when he left the building?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Felt. Felt continues inside. Bates is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Close the door as you leave, Mr. Bates. And as Bates exits, Felt reaches for a phone. Then-- EXT. WASHINGTON, D.C. - SUNDOWN - FELT’S BUICK - AERIAL S The car leaves the monolithic FBI HQ, passes the illumina Capitol, the Lincoln Memorial ... joining the river of ta lights crossing the Potomac into Virginia.  47 48 49 34. EXT. DINER - RURAL VIRGINIA - NIGHT al Felt’s Buick pulls in. INT. FELT’S BUICK - NIGHT 48 Felt just sits there, engine running. Staring inside the diner. At a man, 50, sitting alone in a booth. Felt holding to the wheel. Doesn't want to let go. Then-- INT. DINER - NIGHT 4g Felt slides in across from the man. Time Magazine reporte SANDY SMITH. Half-way through a turkey plate.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You look like hell. Have some food.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (to the waitress) Just coffee. So what does this look like to you?

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or your editors--? This Watergate thing? SMITH (CONT’D) Honestly? No one at Time Magazine, or any newspaper I know of, can figure it out. Ex-spooks get caught, but doing what? Planting bugs? The place was already bugged. The White House may be a bunch of certifiable paranoids, but that stupid? That would be a stupid world record. (another forkful) How ‘bout you? Felt doesn’t reply. That interests Smith. SMITH (CONT’D) Does have a particular odor to it, though. (fishing--) I bet your old pal Bill Sullivan sure misses the FBI. (Felt doesn’t take the bait; Smith casts further) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear the White House gave him some bullshit job until Hoover kicked the bucket. Gray for a little while, keep the seat warm--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Sullivan wants back in. The President wants him back in. To run the FBI their way.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Nixon and Sullivan -- those two were made for each other. Felt gives Smith a long look. Smith knows the look. He ta out a notebook. Felt shakes, No. Sips at his coffee. Wait wanders by. Smith waves her to keep going. SMITH (CONT’D) (exasperated) What’re we doing out here, Mark?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I was given forty-eight hours.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Wrap up the Watergate investigation.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: By who? (no reply; takes a shot) Gray? (Felt’s not saying no) Pat Gray, the FBI Director, ordered the FBI to stop its own investigation??

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: There are calls we aren’t allowed to make, and phone and bank records we can’t go near. And now Felt digs at the pie.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (serious as a heart attack) In all the years I’ve known you you never gave up a single real secret. Nothing but the company line. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are uncharted waters for you. (then) So one more time: what’re we doing? You looking for a little help? A little payback?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I want the FBI left alone to do its job. That’s all I want.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: And you want me to light a fire around the edges. With a story. (as Felt says nothing--) Now I see why they didn’t give you the job. They must be terrified of you. You’re their worst nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt at a window. Stops to look over the fence into the n yard. At his neighbors, a COUPLE. The WIFE comes out and hands the HUSBAND a drink. “Kids asleep?” The mundane normalcy of their everyday life. A He HOLDS there, transfixed, then-- INT. JOAN’S ROOM - FELT HOME - NIGHT 50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt enters. Clicks on the light. A girl’s room frozen mid-breath, everything like it was - pile of marijuana ash -- picture of the updated Joan, the hippie version: thin, grim -- stacks of militant lefty bo and pamphlets. A creak 0.S. in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: What about playing some golf on Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: We don’t play golf.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: We'll get lessons. It’1ll be something new. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss you. I know I’m not supposed to say that.  37.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: It’s okay to say that.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: It’s too touchy-feely. I need you too much. (Felt says nothing) Did you eat?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What? Yes, I ate-- (and after a pause)

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You two always ate as fast as you could. You two were always racing, always playing. Can’t we ever sit around and have a civilized conversation? (long pause) Where were you? The switchboard said they didn’t know where you were.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Because I didn’t tell them.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: What about Mrs. Tschudy? She said she didn’t know either. But you taught her to always say that, didn’t you--?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (calm) Are you making the calls?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I called all her friends. They haven't spoken to her in a year. She disappeared on everybody. It wasn’t just you. (he says nothing) Are you looking for her? Is the most powerful law enforcement organization in the world looking for her--?  51 52 53 38.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Why, is it against the rules?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: We don’t know what they’d find, do we? After a moment, she walks away, saying--

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Pack everything up. I can’t take the mess anymore. (and now cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lano reading the Washington Post, feet up on a desk. We’r the sprawling WASHINGTON FIELD OFFICE, the local FBI prec across the street from HQ.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: (re: something in the paper) Now where the hell did they get that? (just as--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FELT & BATES crossing Pennsylvania Ave. at a clip. Felt w the Post in his hand. Gets a step on Bates, SLAMS into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 AGENTS ERUPT INTO ACTIVITY at the sight of Felt. Hurry to desks, slipping on jackets, shoving piles of mess into drawers. As-- Felt and Bates zig-zaging through desks. Kunkel and Lano converging from different coordinates.

dialogues.speaker: LANO KUNKEL
dialogues.text: (arriving) (spots the Post in What’s going on? Felt’s hand) Let’s take this into my office.  39. 54 INT. KUNKEL’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Felt, Bates, Kunkel and Lano crowd in.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (waves the Post) This story says we know who the Watergate ringleader is.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: What’s your point?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: How the Post knows we know. Then, this morning our Time Magazine pal Sandy Smith called the Director and said he’s prepping a story that the FBI is plotting a whitewash. He said the Director put a 48-hour cap on the investigation.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (furious) Someone in this office is talking to the press. The point, Mr. Lano, is leaks kill investigations.

dialogues.speaker: LANO KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Whoa, first of all-- (eyeing the other Agents pretending to not listen in) Keep it down, Angie.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: If you want to conduct a leak investigation, be my guest, but two hundred field agents from here to L.A. are chasing leads, so you’1l have to ask all them, too.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Tone, in front of Mr. Felt.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: But I will guarantee it wasn't me or any of the guys in this room. Stop. Quiet. Felt levels a look at Lano. Cold, paralyzing  40.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Give me that memo, Mr. Bates. (Bates hands him a “TOP SECRET” folder) “Donald H. Segretti.” You pulled that name from Howard Hunt’s phone records?

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: He called Hunt a few dozen times, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: This says Segretti used to be a lawyer in the Treasury Department. What about these payments?

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: We have a hundred leads we’re tracking.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: This says he was paid out of the account that funded the Watergate. (waiting for this to register) An account belonging to the Committee to Re-Elect the President. (still waiting) Who's the head of the Committee?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: John Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Former Attorney General John Mitchell. Now, paid to do what?

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: Best we can make out Segretti was a kind of prankster, spying on the Dems, sending dirty pictures to their wives. Bottom-feeder frat boy stuff.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Indictable under election laws maybe--  41.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Forget the plot of the story, Mr. Kunkel. What’s the theme? What’s it saying? What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Like Angie - Mr. Lano - said we're still vetting the leads--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: All the ugly politics, all the dirty money, all this sleaze - it means the goddamn punks are running the country! (coming undone, he catches himself, then, calm--) Keep going. (and turns to go, but)

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: You might want to ask the White House about those leaks. (that turns Felt)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: ‘cuz whenever I get lucky enough to get someone over there to actually talk to me, they know what I’m going to ask before I ask it. It's like they already know what I wanna know. 55 INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 55

dialogues.speaker: CAROL/ INTERCOM
dialogues.text: I have the White House, Mr. Felt. Mr. John Dean.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Put him through. (then) Mr. Dean.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/ PHONE
dialogues.text: I have Pat Gray here with me.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Okay.  42.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/ PHONE
dialogues.text: The White House is concerned about these leaks. (pause) We think the source has to be someone in the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Why FBI?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/ PHONE
dialogues.text: That’s where the information is.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: That story could have come from someone in the White House. Stop. We HEAR Dean and Gray conferring in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/ PHONE
dialogues.text: We would like you to do something about it, Mr. Felt.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/ PHONE
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Okay. But I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/ PHONE
dialogues.text: Which part?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: The part about you calling me. Since the Acting Director is with you I’m sure he’s explained that the White House has no authority over the FBI. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/ PHONE
dialogues.text: We can--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: At all. Mr. Dean. More murmurs on the other end. Then--  43.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/ PHONE
dialogues.text: But we can suggest. (Felt says nothing) Thank you, Mr. Felt.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Dean. 56 INT. FELT’/S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 56 Gray enters. Sits heavily at Felt’s desk. Felt takes him

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You know, you might want to stop going over to the White House. It could give some people the wrong idea. Like they’re telling you what to do. (Gray just looks at him, nervous )

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: We got a call from across the river.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Which river is that?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: The Potomac. The CIA. The CIA is telling us we need to taper off.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (calm, almost ironic, disbelief) “Taper off'? The CIA?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: We're getting too close.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Too close to what?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You can’t, or you won’t?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: It’s a matter of national security.  57

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (every syllable) Na-tion-al se-cur-i-ty? Gray looks like he wants to shit, or puke. Then holds up finger, as in “wait”. And spins a pad on Felt’s desk and draws five diamonds in circle. Two more above. Then connects the diamonds with lines. While he’s drawing-- Felt’s not looking at the drawing. He’s looking at Gray. Ignoring the spoken word and looking for the tells and ti

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Can our Watergate investigation be contained to just this? Now Felt’s eyes fall on the diagram. HOLD. Then they move from the folder to Gray’s eyes and HOLD. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Let me guess. These five here, they’re the burglars? (Gray nods) And those two at the top there, the ringleaders, Hunt and Liddy?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: (yes yes) John Mitchell will take responsibility for the whole miserable adventure. He’s agreed.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: The former Attorney General has agreed. To take the fall. (Gray gestures, Yes) Take the fall for who? For what? Gray just sits there. Felt lets him. Then taps the folder

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are the pawns. We want the ones who moved the pawns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates is washing his hands. Another Agent taking a leak. Felt enters. Waits in the middle of the room for the othe Agent to take his cue and split. Felt flashes Bates a scr of paper.  58 45.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I want you to disappear our investigation on these two names. Get them off the interview list.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (reads it) I don’t get it. They’re nobodies.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Just do it. Then make sure you say you did it in Monday’s memo for the Director. Felt flushes the piece of paper and leaves. INT. GRAY’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 58 Bates puts a folder stamped “CONFIDENTIAL” in front of Gr

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Charlie. Bates starts to leave. Gray opens the folder. Inside: a single piece of paper. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much of what we’re getting on Watergate am I actually seeing? (Bates turns at the door)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Mr. Felt gives me the headlines, and I type it up, give Mr. Felt the original, and bring a copy to you. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Felt doesn’t want to waste your time with details.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Okay. Mr. Gray. (and as he leaves, we cut to--)  59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kunkel exits the Judiciary building on foot, heads for th bus stop.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Kunkel! Kunkel turns to find one of Gray’s accountant-like flacks GRAY’S FLACK Director Gray wanted you to know that he understands you and your boys are doing a helluva job. (Kunkel a little confused, but--)

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Tell Mr. Gray thank you. And not to worry, we'll gather the whole ball of yarn. GRAY’S FLACK Mr. Gray also wanted you to know that there is going to be a small change in procedure. In the information flow-- (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How, and, more precisely, where it flows. Not just the headlines, but the story itself. The details, as it were--

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Does Mr. Felt know? GRAY’S FLACK Of course-- (and cut hard to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey, depleted, opens her closet. Revealing a row of wi stands. Heads of hair. Red. Blonde. Falls. Bangs. One hea empty. She peels back the piece on her head, revealing he own hair. Places the wig on the stand, and then we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey's eyes pop awake in bed. She reaches for Felt. He' not there. She gets out of bed.  61 62 63 47. TRACK HER as she sleepily moves from bathroom to hallway her robe, until she’s outside Felt’s office. Until she’s outside Felt’s den. We HEAR the murmur of Felt’s voice: FELT’S VOICE (OVER) You're going to have to find that out, aren’t you? (and hangs up, and--) Audrey opens the door, and goes into-- INT. FELT’S BASEMENT OFFICE 61 Felt’s seated at his raised desk, in his robe, smoking. Audrey takes a cigarette from his pack. He lights it for They regard each other warily.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I never questioned anything, Mark. I never asked. In thirty years.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What did you want to know? (and now) What do you want to know? She knows he’d never tell. He knows she’d never ask.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Who can you talk to? Who do you talk to? Beat. He looks at her. Then, just--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I want you to put this desk back the way it was. (and gets up, and--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt, in his swim suit, faces a patch of forest behind th house. PAINTING on an easel. Felt’s picture isn’t genius, it’s better than we might think. Impressionistic, passion O.S. a phone inside starts to RING. Now cut to-- FELT CROSSING HIS FRONT YARD to the curb, robe over his s paint brush in hand.  64 65 48. Felt climbs into a GOVERNMENT-ISSUE SEDAN. Bates and Mill up front.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Angie Lano called me last night. He told me he’d called the White House to schedule a round of interviews. Felt starts tapping on the back of Miller's seat with the brush. Slow, metronome beats.

dialogues.speaker: BATES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A half hour later the White House called back and said we can’t talk to two of the guys because they were taken off the list. (pause) It was the two names you gave me. STOP. Felt holds the brush still.

dialogues.speaker: BATES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’d the White House know?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I guess somebody told them.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: The only people who knew were me and you.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: And Mr. Gray.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: And Mr. Gray. (and now cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: NIXON/FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: We are doing everything we can to investigate this Watergate incident-— (continuing over--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray exits, joining the flow of federal employees on lunc break, as we're hearing-  66 49.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON/NEWS CONFERENCE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: I'm having White House legal counsel John Dean look into it, and his investigation has so far indicated that no one in the White House staff, no one in this administration, presently employed, was involved in this very bizarre incident-- (cut to--) A REFLECTION IN A WINDOW. The reflection is Felt's. He's his office, watching Gray disappear below into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON/NEWS CONFERENCE, (OVER)
dialogues.text: --What really hurts in dealing with wrongdoing is if you try to cover it up. PAN around to find Miller, Bates and Kunkel standing in t middle of the room. After a long and uncomfortable silenc

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Sit down, Mr. Kunkel. Kunkel sits, confused. The others remain standing.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Mr. Bates tells me you’ve been giving Mr. Gray everything we're collecting on Watergate. All our interviews, our raw files.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Did I do something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Did Mr. Gray tell you to bypass me?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: He didn’t say it was a secret or anything.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: No, you just decided it was.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: But he said you knew.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: How often? Did you give him our files?  50.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Every day.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Did he say why? Kunkel shakes, No.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Did you ask?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: He’s the Director.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Acting Director. Felt and Miller exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: How much have you given him?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: It’s been a coupla weeks.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Christ. A long silence. Kunkel knows he’s screwed up.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Did you give the Attorney General any information about our investigation?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: I don’t talk to the Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Did you, Mr. Bates? (Bates shakes, No) Mr. Miller? (Miller shakes, No--) The Attorney General called me this morning. About something he could only have heard from the FBI. (and now) He’s putting a box around Watergate. We can’t touch anything before the break-in. We have to stay away from all the White House corruption. (in other words--) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The crimes that matter don’t matter. (and--) For the first time in its history, the FBI has been quarantined. Crimes it knows about will go uninvestigated (after a long pause) Thank you, Mr. Kunkel.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL BATES
dialogues.text: Mr. Felt-- Get out, Bob. And Kunkel leaves. When they’re all alone. Felt sits.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: With everything we have right now - if we could get indictments, in your opinion who’d we get? How high?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Maybe Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What about the President? Stop. They look at him.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: If the President’s lying?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Is the President lying?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: They're all lying.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Then yes. Maybe the President. (on the gravity of the moment, now cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: A TV 67
dialogues.text: ABC NEWS AND JIM MCKAY in a Munich beer garden. The start the Olympics less than a week away. While-- OVER, in PRE-LAP, a distant phone starts to RING--  68 69 70 71 72 73 74 75 76 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNDER THE RINGING PHONE, we begin an aerial tour of Feder power and legacy. A series of serene night-time postcard shots of the luminous Washington Monument. The Capitol. T INT. DEN - FELT’S HOME - NIGHT 69 Felt bathed in blue TV light. Special news bulletin: mask PLO GUERILLAS holding hostage ISRAELI ATHLETES on live TV

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: As the phone STILL RINGING, crescendoing slightly, we cut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln memorial ... Jefferson Memorial ... now--

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE SAME RINGING PHONE
dialogues.text: YOUNG MARK FELT, age 9, being bestowed dominion over a yo horse by his FARMER FATHER. Family rite of passage. Young Mark’s loving pride over this animal. And now we back ins

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt now, on the phone, eying TV coverage of the carnage Munich. Burning helicopters. Burnt bodies. And as the RINGING CONTINUES OVER--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're over the Pentagon, slowing over its majesty. Then b to-- YOUNG MARK WORRYING OVER THE HORSE, which is clearly very ill. Felt’s father silently accusing his son. Young Mark grief-stricken, falls to his knees and prays. Back to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just holding there. Then back to--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MARK AND FATHER 76
dialogues.text: 77 78 79 80 53. standing over the horse, now collapsed and struggling for breath. Mark’s face sets with an expression we now know well: caged emotion. As Mark puts a pistol to the horse’s temple. Then--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MARK ON KNEES 77
dialogues.text: scrubbing blood off the barn floor and walls. Weeping silently with rage and--

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SCREEN. AND STOP.
dialogues.text: Nothing. No sound. Then: CRACK! THE GUNSHOT.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: FELT’S EYES RIPPING OPEN. 78 He’s lying in bed in the bedroom in the dark. Woken from memory. He looks to Audrey. She’s not there. The phone is RINGING. (The phone we've been hearing.)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (picks up) What is it? (and smash to--) THAT PENTAGON MAJESTY ... Then: 79

dialogues.speaker: KA-BOOM
dialogues.text: A giant fireball RIPS through the Pentagon’s second floor Burning glass and debris billow into the sky. Now back to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt on the phone in his robe. At the window, looking out into the back yard.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY / PHONE
dialogues.text: (freaked) What about the White House?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: It’s at the top of the Underground’s hit list. I told you that three months ago.  54.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY / PHONE
dialogues.text: (panicked) But can they really hit it?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: They just hit the Pentagon. What Felt is seeing outside: poolside, the cherry of a si cigarette surges in the night. The shape of Audrey on a chaise. On the wall behind him, a portrait of Joan.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY / PHONE
dialogues.text: I want us to open files on every member of every counter-culture organization in the country.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (watching his wife) They’re mostly kids. We’re looking for killers, not moody teenagers.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY / PHONE
dialogues.text: The President is fighting for the White House--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: That’s not my job. We need better intelligence, not paperwork--

dialogues.speaker: GRAY / PHONE
dialogues.text: (losing it) The President needs order! I promised the President he’d have order!

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’ll go to the Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY / PHONE
dialogues.text: I already spoke to the Attorney General. And there it is. Beat of tense silence.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY/PHONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hear you and your wife are registered Democrats, Mark. (suddenly oddly personal) I hope you’re not going to let that get in the way. (and Gray hangs up, and--) Felt lowers into the chair. HOLD on him, then we find--  81 82 83 84 55. FELT ASLEEP. Now SNAPPING AWAKE. Heard something. Somethi sharp. Gunshot.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Audrey? Audrey?! He’s up. Running for the basement. The door open. Felt bounding down the stairs. STOPPING--

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no -- Oh no -- OH NO! We see what he sees: AUDREY IN A POOL OF HER OWN BLOOD. Felt’s service revolve beside her. She’s blown her brains out. He’s on his knees. Cradling her body, her head - the mess in his hands. First the horse. Now her. And now-- SCRUBBING the basement floor. Scrubbing the mess away. As scrubbed the horse’s blood. Sobbing. Furiously. Erasing t mess. NOW-- WE HEAR FOOTSTEPS come down the stairs. Felt doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mark? (and now smash to--)

dialogues.speaker: OMIT. 83
dialogues.text: INT. BASEMENT OFFICE - FELT’S HOME - LATER 84

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey slow-steps half-way down the steps to the basement She stops. Then we HEAR why: THIS IS THE SOUND OF FELT SOBBING. It could be that Audrey’s never heard him cry before. Com around on Felt, awash in tears. About this and every othe thing. Audrey heads back up. Without going to him. Hoping he doe notice. He hears, turns to look for her just as she withdraws int the upper reaches of the house. Behind him now, no body. Felt on his knees in the middle of the floor. Alone. And go from that human loss to the mechanical clatter of--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN ACROSS A DOZEN YOUNG PROTESTERS waking from a night o sit-in protest, amid their trash and radical signage. CAMERA FINDS FELT in his black suit stepping carefully am the kids. Contemplating their faces.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Hey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recognition) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN stirs. A BABY BOY in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: What the fuck, creep!

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. You look like my-- like someone I know.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: You look like an undertaker.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. (maybe laughs a little at himself) What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: You a cop?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I'm just someone looking for someone else.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: April.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: April. Pretty. How about your son?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: River.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: River? Okay. River. Your parents know you’re out here?  55B.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Whoa, way early for the interrogation. But man, right now I just really wanna pee.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Maybe you can use a little help? You and your boy there? (and reaches for his wallet)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t want your money.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Your parents would want someone to do this. They’d want someone to take care of you. And he’s pulling out a few tens. She won’t take them. He them in the baby’s little hands. They fall like leaves an picks them up and tries again then just leaves the girl a the money, and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GIANT COMPUTER SPITTING OUT an endless stream of names. Paper drifts across the floor. Felt watching with the YOU AGENT whose sorry job it is to keep an eye on all this.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG AGENT
dialogues.text: (no idea who Felt is) The Radical Youth List. Felt now grabs a handful of photos from a two-foot high stack. Mug shots. Surveillance photos. Year book photos. young. Some children.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What did these people do?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG AGENT
dialogues.text: Shoplifted. Cut school. Wrote an angry letter to the White House.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Protestors?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG AGENT
dialogues.text: Them too. Doesn’t take much these days. (now Felt picks up some of the print out and starts to read)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Where’s this data coming from?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG AGENT
dialogues.text: CIA, FBI, NSA, local police, staties, Time, Newsweek, speeches, anonymous tips, high school yearbooks. Everywhere, nowhere. It's like the machine's out of control. No matter how much data we pour into it it's still hungry. The photos. The names.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: This could be every kid in America. (and grabbing an armful of print-out and exiting)

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG AGENT
dialogues.text: Looking for someone in particular?  86 87 88 INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY Felt enters with the print-out.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (urgent) White House twice Attorney General three times and Mr. Gray’s waiting-- Felt DROPS the pile of paper on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Shred all this. (then cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt and Gray striding together down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bates and Miller and three others waiting around a long table. Felt and Gray enter. War Room.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (nods to Miller) Go.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: The Palestinian unit that slaughtered the Israelis is going to try to hit us here. Airports in New York, Baltimore, Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: This connected to the Pentagon?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: The Palestinians are talking to the Weather Underground. Sharing information. We knew that; we just didn’t know what it meant.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Now we do. They’re combining. They're multiplying. All eyes on Felt. Except Felt’s. He’s staring at Gray.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: (out of his depth) We sure about this? (Miller nods) Dammit. Then hunt them. Hunt them to exhaustion. No holds barred.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You can tell the President the FBI will give him his order.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I'll leave you all to it then. (and he leaves, and--)

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: We'll never get warrants. Not now.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Warrants? We’re not talking the kids sleeping out there in the parks. (pointing out there) We're talking about people who would burn your children alive in their beds. If people die because we stick to the letter of the law, we lose everything. Including the law. (and so now--) We're taking off the gloves. Entries, taps. Nothing on paper. No warrants. (Miller and Bates put down their pens) Mr. Miller’s people report to Mr. Miller, Mr. Miller reports to me--

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Just like the bad ole’ days. Where’s Bill Sullivan when you really need him?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (explodes ) He’s over at the White House protecting the nation by spying on Senators and their mistresses! Here, let me give you his goddamn number, and you can go work with him! Instead of here, where we’re just trying to keep all this goddamn mess together!  59. STOP. Long tense silence. Felt never raises his voice. No All leave.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: (voice of reason) Hey, look, we’re on your side. All I’m saying is, that was all behind us. Even Hoover knew the dirty stuff was over. That’s why Bill’s gone. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I’m saying is, everyone's watching. (and Felt turns on him now)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: How many more kids do we have to lose? How many more do we just let vanish into eternity? (and they all know what he’s really talking about, what he really means; then; steel) [I am not Bill Sullivan.] This is still the goddamn FBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except Felt. And Miller. When they are alone--

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: I don’t want to intrude--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Then don’t.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Hear anything? From Joan?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (softer than we expect) Nothing in six months. She could be anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: You think she’s involved? In all this? The Underground? Felt looks at him. Hit. Internally buckling--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: How could she. She’s just like me. Exactly like me. (and Miller nodding, yes, that’s it)  89 90 60.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: She worships you. You are her moon and stars. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's okay. I can feel it, Mark. And that stops him. “Mark”?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: There’s a price to pay for what we do, Mr. Miller. There’s a price to pay for what we become. We all pay it, one way or another. (and turns, and leaves Miller standing there, and cut to--) INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 89 Felt shuts the door, sits. Takes a breath. We PAN AROUND see he’s contemplating that photo of Joan.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL/INTERCOM, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Felt on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
