dialogues.text: Take a message. (and--) Takes a stack of 50 blank envelopes out of his briefcase. Taps them to align edges. Pulls out his wallet, and out o that a folded piece of paper. PUSH IN CLOSE and we SEE a list of addresses written in Felt’s impeccable calligraphy-like script. With painstaking precision, Felt starts addressing envelo Each to a different address, but every one in California. INT. FELT’S HOME - LATER THAT NIGHT 90

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indian summer. The air thick. Felt enters in his suit, ha

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Audrey? Nothing. Goes deeper into the house. We pick up the SOUND ice tumbling in a glass. Felt is stopped in the den, by t sight of her outside, in the dark, pool lights off. Knows what that means. Braces himself, and And he heads out to-  91 61. EXT. BACK YARD - FELT’S HOME 91 Audrey's smoking and drinking on a chaise poolside, contemplating the night. Felt approaches. She hands the cigarette up. Felt takes a drag, hands it back. He sips a her drink. Bottle of gin by her foot.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Maybe she’s dead. Maybe she just gave up, didn’t think anyone cared. Or christ-- (and waves at the woods) Maybe she never left. Maybe she’s right out there, watching us. To see what a man like you does when your daughter just vanishes one night for no good reason.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Joan had a reason for everything.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Oh, [here we go again] it was my fault?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You hated her.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Mothers don’t hate their daughters! It’s just not always easy being one!

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: She was beautiful and smart. You dressed her up like a doll. Until she got old enough to look just like you. You were jealous. And you hated her for it--

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mark. Don’t-- You kept telling her to get out. Until one day she listened to you.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm begging you listen to me. But she did-- I had no mother-

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No. Listen to me! (and she takes his hands) My mother was 47 when she had me. And my father just left. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There weren’t many ways for a woman to support herself, to survive-- (and Felt slows; this is new; hearing this for the first time--) --So yes, she did, she gave me up. To foster homes. She didn’t want to lose her daughter completely. But then the orphanage. And then she just stopped coming back-- (and stops herself; this biblical realization) Felt lowering to a chair, lights a cigarette. Listening. Always collecting clues to his wife. As she goes on--

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And when I was eleven, I was placed in that home, and I loved it. They told me to call them mom and dad. But they told me to my face that they'd keep me only until I went into puberty. As soon as I had my first period I was out, because they didn’t want to deal with all that. All that womanhood, and boys. So when I got my first period I didn’t want to leave. I hid the rags. And I had to use rags, to wash myself, after everyone went to bed so they wouldn’t know. And then they did find out. And then I was just gone. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I made it on my own. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until you. My white knight. You’re everything to me. The homes we made were the only homes I ever had. When you walk into a room you're the only thing I see.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You are both mine. And now tries to embrace her. Mine. The phone starts ring inside the house. And just as quickly the moment is lost-

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t (leave)-- I need to get that.  63. And he watches her cross to the kitchen and then to the phone. Watching her through the window pick up the phone. Chipper. Like nothing has happened.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? ... Oh, hi, Margaret ... No I never made it, I was swamped with house work... (and now--) Felt turns to the pool. Stands there a beat. Strips off h shirt. His pants. Then slips into the water. Until he’s gone beneath a rash bubbles. And we stay with-- FELT’S POV. Looking from the bottom up at a rectangle of Audrey in view, wavy through the interference of water. Felt about to burst. But can’t rise. Hungry for the quiet dark isolation. Desperate for the safety of the coming de Until a beat before drowning we rise with him. And he EXPLODES to the surface, GASPING FOR BREATH. And lifts himself out of the pool. Dripping and shivering Listening to Audrey gossip, we BEGIN TO HEAR in PRE-LAP:

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY GENERAL RICHARD KLEINDIENST
dialogues.text: (PRE-LAP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three-hundred thirty-three Agents from fifty-one field offices around the country developed one-thousand eight-hundred and ninety-seven leads... (and we cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: KLEINDIENST/TV
dialogues.text: ...one-thousand five-hundred and fifty-one interviews, spending fourteen-thousand ninety-eight man hours. Watergate was the most intensive, objective and thorough investigation in the history of the U.S. Attorney’s office and the FBI. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY GENERAL RICHARD
dialogues.text: The Justice Department has now completed its criminal investigation without implicating any present officials of either the White House or the Committee to Re- elect the President.

dialogues.speaker: LANO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Completed?? What the hell? (PULL BACK TO REVEAL--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lano and Kunkel watching the TV. Ten Agents crowd the doo

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Somebody get me Felt on the phone. As the news CUTS TO a SIMULTANEOUS JOHN DEAN NEWS CONFERE

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold on-- wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/TV
dialogues.text: Ties to the White House? Two former White House people, low level, indicted, one consultant and one member of the Domestic Council staff. That's not very much of a tie. (then) I understand the FBI’s Watergate investigation is in a state of repose and unlikely to be reopened. (and back to--)

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Anybody tell us this thing was over?!

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR/TV, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, just forty-two days before election day, President Nixon’s approval ratings continue to rocket-- Kunkel MUTES the TV.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Where the hell’s Felt? Or Bates. Goddammit get Felt on the phone!  93 65.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: Because he’s right there. They turn to the shitty little TV. And so do we: Where Felt is standing like a stone lion on one side of t Attorney General, Gray on the other. Matching bookends of authority. Playing his role. Then cut to-- INT. GRAY’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 93 Felt enters. Disturbed by what he’s just done.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: How’s home, Mark?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: That daughter of yours? Jill?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Joan.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I hear she’s terrific. Fulbright scholar! First girl in the country! Chip off the old block. (after a heavy silence) Have a seat. (Felt stays standing, which Gray notes - “okay” - but just--) I want you to be the first to hear my statement to the press. (reading) ‘No pressure has been put on me or any of my special agents in the FBI’s investigation, and that it strains’ -- I thought I would just nip this in the bud -- ‘it strains credulity that President Nixon could have done a con job on the whole American people.’ (looks up) What do you think?  94 66.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: It’s just fine.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Our job is done. Tie up the loose ends. Then shut it all down. (and after a beat--)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (simply) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The daily meeting. All 27 Agents. Felt and Bates against the back wall. All acutely aware o and not particularly happy with - their presence.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: (grim) The Democrats issued a statement this morning. (reading) “The FBI's Watergate investigation is a whitewash--” PUSH IN ON FELT while hearing the rest of this. He redden Jaw clenches. Hands clench into fists...

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL, (OVER)
dialogues.text: --"What is involved here is not only the political life of this nation, but the very morality of our leaders at a time when the United States desperately needs to revitalize its moral standards--” (it’s killing Felt, like nothing else could kill Felt) That’s it. Despondent silence. Nothing left to say. Then--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen, here’s what we know. We know what we’ve heard out of the Department of Justice the last two days is bullshit. (he has their attention) We know the men who broke into the Watergate are not the end of this thing but the beginning. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We know this is the latest link in a chain of illegal covert intelligence operations by the President's re-election campaign. We know we are facing obstruction from multiple fronts. From the White House. From the Central Intelligence Agency. From the Attorney General of the United States. Who is our boss. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not our job to speculate on the involvement of the President. It is our job to follow the bread crumbs. But those bread crumbs appear to be taking us on a tour of the West Wing of the White House, and in the general direction of the Oval Office. We also know we’ve been ordered to shut down our pursuit of all this as of today. And we know that except for the thirty men in this room no one in the entire country knows any of this, and may never know any of this-- Unless we tell them. (and now) No one can stop the driving force of an FBI investigation. Not even the FBI. The agents are stunned. Energized. Felt outwardly calm, b as we MOVE IN TIGHTER, we see he is vibrating with rage.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what else? (and then we find him--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt and Bates walking briskly back to FBI HQ. INT. FELT’/S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 96 CAROL sorting Felt’s mail. Comes on one of the envelopes had mailed. It’s stamped ‘Return to sender’. She adds it stack of five just like that. She walks the envelopes to Felt.  97 98 99 68. Felt stares at the “return to senders”. He pulls out the of addresses, neatly checks off the ones that have come b It's almost half of them now. He unlocks a bottom drawer and lifts out a neat stack of twenty of the same envelopes. Looks up. Carol has not moved. She is standing in the middle of the room looking at him. Connecting and speaking with her eye And, finally, nod. Of knowing. And support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt sits at his easel. Autumn leaves whirlpooling around him. His paint brush an inch away from the surface, froze mid-air. His EYES FIXED we think on the woods, contemplat maybe the lean of a tree. Now cut to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a wall of window glass letting out onto the stree we see Audrey in private class with a YOUNG INSTRUCTOR. H sexy, virile. She is heavily made up. We stay wide, long. They salsa excellently across the frame. Sultry. Close. N

FELT AT HIS EASEL. PAN AROUND and SEE the canvas is perfe white. And his eyes fixed not on a tree but an idea. And to-- AUDREY and instructor, gyrating, spinning. Faster like a picking up speed. Head tipped. Drunk. In both ways. Then back to and-- PUSH IN CLOSE ON THE TIP OF FELT’S BRUSH. A bead of paint drops, and we follow its fall ... and as it SPLASHES on Felt’s knee-- EXT./INT. LAUNDROMAT/FELT’S CAR - NIGHT 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt’s Buick pulls up. Stops at a phone booth. Rain drums hard against the windows. Felt’s not getting out. He’s sitting there watching the rain. On the seat beside him, and FBI memo stamped “Confidentia PUSH IN on the memo. TIGHT ON: “Shipley ...Segretti. Whit House ...political espionage...sabotage... Now up to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt. He’s thinking about his life and its consequences.  69. This is very much like that moment in the life of a man w has not yet cheated on his wife, but who is staring at a motel room door, on the other side of which lies a woman whom there will be no debate. Once he goes through that d life as he knows it will never be the same. Felt gets out of the car. Steps into the booth. Dimes. Di

dialogues.speaker: VOICE/PHONE
dialogues.text: (picking up--) Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I'm going to give you the name of a man who was asked to go to work for the Nixon administration in an unusual way.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE/PHONE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I'm talking about political sabotage, crimes conceived in the White House, and run out of the White House. (pause) It’s all linked.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE/PHONE
dialogues.text: To what?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Watergate. (now a long quiet, then--) There is only one way to understand what Watergate really means, and this is it. (then) The name is Alex Shipley. Shipley. He lives in Nashville. The man who approached him was a lawyer out of L.A. named Donald Segretti. Segretti. S-E-G-R-E-T-T-I. (then) Shipley can tell you everything you need to know.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE/PHONE
dialogues.text: Will Shipley talk?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I guess you’re going to have to find that out. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) One more thing. This comes from confidential FBI files. The Department of Justice has it. The White House has it. And now you have it.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE/PHONE
dialogues.text: Why do you have it?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You'll have to find that out, too. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But first I want you to give it to somebody for me.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE/PHONE
dialogues.text: Who am I supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You’re a government lawyer, aren’t you? Just tell them that. (and we fall back outside, past the glass) And watch Felt continue talking for a moment. Then he han up, and we smash cut to-- 100 INT. /EXT. FELT’S BUICK (MOVING) /STREETS - NIGHT 100 Felt slows up to and stops outside the dance studio. He watches the Young Instructor work a class of adults. His hands liberally on the hips of someone else’s wife. 101 INT. FELT’/S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 101 Felt sphinx-like at his desk with an expression of bored hostility. Bates and Kunkel monitoring against the wall. PAN to the man lowering himself in the chair across from Felt: 27, tweed jacket, earnest, nervous: BOB WOODWARD.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: (flustered) Mr. Felt--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: A pleasure to meet you.  71.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: (confused, a little panicked) I didn’t have much time to prepare.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: The FBI likes to extend courtesy to the press whenever it can, and Mr. Felt had a sudden opening. So, the usual rules. Mr. Felt will only confirm or deny. Nothing on the record or on background. Woodward looks to Felt. Felt is imperious and blank. Felt nods.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: (making it up) Okay, so, regarding the break-in at the Watergate. We have Hunt standing outside the hotel that night.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’1l confirm.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: And we have two ex-CIA and two ex- FBI agents involved. Woodward dutifully makes a note.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this check deposited in the account of one of the burglars. (Woodward and Felt hold a look) It was a CIA account, correct?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: That is true. But I won’t confirm.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: You just said it was true.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: That doesn’t mean we want people to know that it’s true. So I won't confirm it.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: I need more detail.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Get it somewhere else.  72. Pause. Woodward looks again to Felt for a sign. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: (surprised) That’s it? That’s what you want? You know how many people get to sit in that seat? Woodward takes a breath, throws what he guesses is the pa he was brought here to throw.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: Just one more thing, I guess. Someone identifying himself as a ‘government lawyer’ called my colleague at the Post, Carl Bernstein, two nights ago. He gave us a name. (reading from notes) Alex Shipley. Bates and Kunkel shoot each other an amazed look. Felt’s simply doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Where’d you get that?

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: He’s the Assistant Attorney General of Tennessee.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: We know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: But is Shipley an FBI target?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL BATES
dialogues.text: No comment! We're not going to comment on that.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’m not going to comment on that.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: Shipley told my colleague--

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: You already spoke to Shipley?!  73.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: Shipley was recruited - they tried to recruit him - to perform political espionage on behalf of the Nixon administration. He gave us the name of the recruiter. (from notes) Donald C. Segretti. Felt: nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: No comment!

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: Segretti we know is a former Treasury Department lawyer--

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: No comment!

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: No comment. STOP. Silence. Woodward looks up, bemused. Knows now why brought him here--

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: But I haven’t asked anything yet.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: CAROL SHOVING WOODWARD OUT THE DOOR, then back to-- Felt, Bates and Kunkel.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Jesus christ who the hell’s talking to these guys?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: ‘Government lawyer’ could be ten thousand people in this town. They're semi-hysterical. Felt calm as shit.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Get Mr. Lano over to the Post. Find out where they’re getting their information.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Gladly.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: And I want all our offices swept for bugs. Today.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Who would be crazy enough to bug the FBI? (Felt and Bates look at each other)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Whoever thinks they need to know what we know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (picking up) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: FELT / PHONE
dialogues.text: (another extension) I have it. (she keeps listening; a silence, then--) Please hang up. She won't let go. Then she does. And goes to the sink. Felt enters.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Are you having an affair, Mark? (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I’m starting to wish you were.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Are you? (but didn’t mean to say it, and before she can answer) They’ve unplugged the system, and the FBI system is beautiful. We all knew where we fit in. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do our jobs and the machine gets it right. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no heroes. Not now. Not anymore.  103 75. Felt exits, crosses to the driveway to his car in the carport. He gets in, and he backs out, and then we cut to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt in the phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD /PHONE
dialogues.text: Summoning me to the FBI like that--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (into phone) It wasn’t about you. Our conversations have to be protected. (then) Where did you get Shipley?

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD /PHONE
dialogues.text: The source won’t give his name.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Shipley’s good information. You're on it now ... But we can’t do this by phone any more. This is more dangerous than you realize.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD /PHONE
dialogues.text: How dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: When we meet you’1ll have to observe strict rules of counter- surveillance. How do you leave your apartment?

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD / PHONE
dialogues.text: Front door.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (into phone) Take the alley. Don’t drive your own car. Take a taxi but switch taxies mid-way. Take the time you need. One hour, two hours. I won’t care if you're late, but if you’re being followed do not come near me. (he looks at his watch) 2 a.m. (and hangs up)  104 105 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN STANDING SUBMERGED IN SHADOW. We’re in a parking garage. The man is smoking. It’s only when the cherry sur that we see it’s Felt. Woodward approaches. They stand there in silence. Both anxious, but for differ reasons. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: The story isn’t moving. Everyone stopped listening to you.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: We're lost in detail.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: That’s their plan. They want everyone confused. Confusion is control. A pause. Woodward is lost.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: This is hard.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Of course it’s hard. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk now.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: We found Segretti.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Segretti’s important but don’t fall in love with him. He connects the pieces, but it runs all over the map. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything was part of it. It’s a monster. (then) The truth could ruin the administration, and I mean ruin. (Woodward just looks at him, then--)  77.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: How high. Does it go? And Felt a sudden recoil of shame, regret--

dialogues.speaker: FELT WOODWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to do this my way! (flash of anger) There’s no going back now! A MATCH FLARES. Now we really see why Felt’s stretching t out. He’s nervous. Afraid. He seems thinner. Worn.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You still don’t understand what I’m giving you. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watergate is just a little corner of a massive conspiracy. Campaign spying and sabotage. Everyone and everything - and I mean everyone - is involved. (Woodward scribbling) The FBI did its job. It’s all in the files. If you put out the right story the public will scream. The Attorney General will have to let me keep going.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: When you do, what are you going to find? They look at each other, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: This is dangerous stuff you’re playing with. Especially if it’s known before November 7th.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: (realizing) Election day.  78.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: The White House is behind everything. But if they get past the election, they’re home free. The President is safe. And now he realizes.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: The President. That’s how high. Felt turns away. We think for good. Then stops. Leaning against a car. Bends his knees, slowly lowers. Until he’s sitting on the cold cement. Tired. At the end of somethin Woodward sits on the garage floor opposite him, cross-leg

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My editors know. That I’m talking to somebody. (Felt looks up sharply) But not who. They don’t ask. [Like they’re afraid to know. ] (Felt looks furious) I'm not going to tell anyone who you are. That’s the deal, I understand. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they know it’s someone deep inside. Someone who can see everything. No one understands how one person knows so much.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: No one can possibly know how much I know. He means about everything, of course. Not just this. A pa then--

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: With all this mystery, there’s a nickname for you at the paper. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘Deep Throat’. Felt stares at him. As if not metabolizing. As if not hav heard. Then his look forms a shape: distaste, disgust.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They didn’t know what else to call you.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: They shouldn’t have to call me anything. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take out your notebook. There’s more. (and now we cut to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey standing barefoot on the lawn, the Washington Post her hands. She’s scanning the front page.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: PUSH IN CLOSE ON THE PAPER - HEADLINE: “FBI Finds Nixon A Sabotaged Democrats”.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: (reading) “FBI agents have established that the Watergate bugging incident stemmed from a massive campaign of political spying and sabotage conducted on behalf of President Nixon's re-election...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt stirs his Folger’s at the kitchen sink. Reading to h from the table.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: “,..and directed by officials of the White House and the Committee for the Re-election of the President. Nixon knows that something is being done. It’s a typical deal, Segretti said. It’s don’ t-ask-and-I-won’t-tell.” Felt’s spoon STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “'There is some very powerful information,’ said one federal official. ‘Especially if it’s known before November 7th.’” (and looks at Felt) Election day--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I know what day it is.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: “The FBI Finds”? This is you-- HOLDING on Felt’s calm mask. As he gets up to face everyt this day will bring, picks up his hat, briefcase, heads o

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are they going to do to us? (then smash to--) INT. FELT’S BUICK (STATIONARY A108 In the driveway. Engine running. Felt’s face all wrong. Gripping the wheel. Listening to--

dialogues.speaker: NEWS BROADCAST/RADIO, (OVER)
dialogues.text: --The White House is vigorously denouncing the story in the Washington Post this morning accusing the administration of engaging in a secret political war. White House press secretary Ron Ziegler is calling the story a “pack of scurrilous lies and innuendo based on faceless cowardly sources inside the Department of Justice.” (and now SMASH to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt steps out of a crowded elevator, having the breezy workaday exchanges a man who runs the FBI would have.

dialogues.speaker: CAR RADIO, (OVER)
dialogues.text: White House is calling the story a “pack of scurrilous lies and innuendo based on faceless cowardly sources inside the Department of Justice.” As Felt goes deeper into HQ, Felt’s POV (which is our POV literally warps: hyper-aware of Agents carrying copies of Post, reading the Woodward/Bernstein story. He imagines e face, every gesture, every set of eyes accusing him. THEY KNOW IT WAS HIM.  109 110 111 81.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (taking his hat and coat) The Director wants you immediately. SHE KNOWS IT WAS HIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. GRAY’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - CONTINUOUS 109 Felt enters. The Post sits on Gray’s desk. It’s been obsessively marked with lines and question marks.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: (picks up the paper) He’s here, Mark, has to be. There’s a spy in the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (OVER)
dialogues.text: (screaming) “,..FBI agents have established"?? (obviously reading from the story) “One federal investigative official said ... according to FBI reports...” (then) THAT’S US, GODDAMMIT! 111

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt, Gray and Bates standing at the top of a conference room. They're facing Kunkel, Lano and the 26 Field Agents the Washington Field Office.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: With Gray, raking cold condemnation over the men.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: (seething) There is information in here that the Bureau only got 72 hours ago! Gentlemen, are you goddamn joking?? (then) Mr. Felt, you had something you wanted to say.  82.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: The last few days I’ve heard various people accuse Mr. Lano of leaking to the press.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: (reddening) You have got to be kidding me. Murmurs. Eyes turn on Lano.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: And that he and certain newspaper reporters have been seen together.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: Think I’m gonna be sick. NOW BATES begins what will become a long escalating stare Felt, putting something together.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I wanted to say to you, Mr. Lano, in front of everyone here, that I know these are vicious lies by jealous agents. You’re doing a fine job, and no matter what the Director and I will support you. Felt nods it back to Gray.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I may not be a FBI lifer like some of you. I’m certainly no Mark Felt. Since I arrived here I have put up with paranoia, insubordination, second-guessing. Gentlemen, it’s Come to Jesus time. Whoever the leaker is, whoever is the Judas among you betraying me, the other good men in this room, his family, God, not to mention the Bureau and the legacy of J. Edgar Hoover, step forward. Right here. Right now. STOP. A hugely tense and awkward moment. FELT - outwardly on fire ... But CLOSER: a trace of sweat eyes flicking face to face. Who knows? Which ones know? KUNKEL - staring at his shoes, humiliated. LANO - fuck you. And back to--  112 83. FELT - stronger and safer every second that ticks by. And back to-- BATES - he’s staring at Felt. Doesn’t want to be thinking what he’s thinking. But here he is thinking it. No one’s stepping forward. Gray stalks out. Bates now absolutely can’t take his eyes off Felt. Becaus Bates REALLY KNOWS. The room empties. Lano pulls Bates aside.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: (whisper) Hey, Charlie, we got an office pool going across the street on who the leak is. My money's on you. INT. BATES’ OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 112 Bates packing years of memorabilia, files and junk into boxes. Kunkel wanders in.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What’s the body count?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Eight so far. You, me, a few guys on my team.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Angie?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: (shakes No) The guy’s a cockroach. He’d survive a nuclear blast.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Where they sending you?

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: St. Louis. You?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: At least it’s Frisco.  84.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Yeah? Good. (tearing up) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: How many years you put in here, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: The whole run. My kids were born here. A long beat, then--

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: Did you know? (Bates just looks at him) About Felt.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What about him? A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: BATES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you? Kunkel seems to sag. Implode. Shrink.

dialogues.speaker: KUNKEL
dialogues.text: I do now.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Some things are bigger than you and me, Bobby. It has to be that way. Kunkel waits, but there’s nothing else to say, so he just leaves.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (TV)
dialogues.text: Did I hear right, my friends? Are we not twenty points ahead?! PULL BACK TO REVEAL the TV’s in  113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cop-and-fireman joint. Felt, Miller and Bates drinking the bar. Miller brings over beers.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I appreciate you taking the time, Mr. Felt. Felt looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: (quietly) Mark--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I always take care of my people, Mr. Bates. In fact, my father always said to me, ‘Mark, whatever we do, we have to make our lives vectors. Lines with force and direction.’ 85. 113 And makes some stabbing motion with his hand. Forward. Fo Bates and Miller exchange a glance. Felt’s drunk as shit.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So he gave me a horse. Yeah, I hadda horse. When I was a boy. My daddy gave it to me to teach me how to protect something, bring it along, be a man about things. A man with vectors. More stabbing. They’re nodding. Pretending to understand.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Catches sick. Bad sick. I got on my knees and prayed to God to save that horse, and to save me. Because everything I was was on the line, Mr. Miller.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Pride, faith in God, my father’s respect. (beat; then) He put the gun in my hand and said I had to shoot that horse myself. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I looked the horse in the eyes and I shot him looking him straight in the eyes. (to Miller) I destroyed that sick horse the way you have to destroy anything that is sick beyond repair. To rescue it from its agony.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Mark-- (and makes a move to take him away, but--)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: And the agony it causes everyone else . Mr. Bates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood never really comes off wood plank, you know. Seeps in like paint. (then) Failed that horse ... Failed my father ... Failed. And so had to destroy.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD, (OVER)
dialogues.text: (TV)

dialogues.speaker: YEARS
dialogues.text: ee

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: Nixon flashing his Victory V's.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: That’s a sad story, Mr. Felt. Felt’s emotional. Drunker than they thought. Vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: BATES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Felt? Bates is going to do it, ask him straight out. Miller can feel it coming. Felt turns, Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: (low) What are you doing, Charlie? (long excruciating beat) Do not--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (his imperiousness returns) What is it, Mr. Bates? Bates can’t do it. Raises a glass:

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Here’s to you. Bravo. They toast.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: San Francisco, Charlie. Plum assignment. They were going to send you to Omaha. Wanted you to know. I watch out for my men and their families. INT. FELT’S HOME - LATER THAT NIGHT Tick-tock go the clocks. The herds of china elephants kee watch. Efrem Zimbalist Jr. wheels and fires from the wall the den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt’s smoking at his desk, Coltrane playing in the b.g. little unsteady, a little drunk. Lets his eyes close. Slo 114 g 115  116 87. Smoke curling up his face. Deeply listening to the music. saxophone runs and the controlled chaos of the improv. Th gunfire drumming. His eyes open. Vigilant. He takes out of his briefcase tw more ‘return-to-sender’ letters. Pulls the address list o of his wallet. Been refolded and thumbed up a hundred tim now. Felt checks off these last addresses. Flattens the list o the desk. WE MOVE IN ON THE LIST: just one address left: Genesis Commune, Ben Lomand, California. Felt picks up the phone. Dials. And we cut to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. BATES fumbles for the receiver, turns on bed light. His wife wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Hello? (now intercutting--)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: One last thing before you leave us, Mr. Bates.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Of course. Hold on. (and reaches for something to write on)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Genesis Commune. Ben Lomand. California. Bates scratches down the name.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Check it thoroughly.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Do we think the Underground's there?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: No muscle, Mr. Bates. Nothing in the files. I want you to handle it personally.  117 118 88.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. What are we looking for?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Joan Felt. My daughter. Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Is the morning okay? Or right now? Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: FELT BATES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Morning’s fine. And Mr. Yes, Mr. Felt? Bates.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You can leave what you find with Mr. Miller.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Mr. Miller. Good night, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Good night. (and hangs up, and--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt comes in. But he’s not the first one in this morning GRAY’S OFFICE DOOR is open. WE PUSH INTO THE OFFICE. Find JOHN DEAN talking to Gray. Dean turns, locks eyes with Felt. Gray closes the door. INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - LATER 118

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt enters. Finds Gray sitting in his chair. (Internally drives Felt crazy.)

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: These leaks are driving the White House crazy. (and looks up) The White House thinks it knows who it is. He’s here. In the FBI. (and then) Your name came up. STOP. Long beat. Felt’s head has filled with a low-level like static interference.  89.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what that would mean?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Treason. For one. Betrayal of everything the FBI stands for. For another. (and then) Everything you stand for. The humming crescendoing. What did he miss? Who overheard him? Now Felt EYES the room for a good place to plant a b

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: So why would I do it?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I can’t imagine their thinking.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Why don’t they fire me?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: They’re terrified of you. You know everything. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To them, the only thing worse than keeping you is firing you. THE HUM DOMINANT NOW. Felt’s pov pinballing around the ro now: Where’s that damn bug?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dean did say something strange. Apparently they know everything going on inside our shop. They have a “source”.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Inside the FBI?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: He said they hear everything. (HOLD, then smash to) Al19 FELT FEELING UNDER THE DESK. Gray’s left the room. F alone. Eyeballing every surface, every corner. MRS. TSCHUDY enters with a stack of folders.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Can I get you an aspirin?  119 90.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Have Mr. Bates sweep our offices for bugs.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Mr. Bates is gone, Mr. Felt.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Have Mr. Miller do it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We just had your office swept, Mr. Felt.

dialogues.speaker: DO IT AGAIN
dialogues.text: And Carol bolts. Felt’s staring hard at Joan’s picture on wall. He takes it down, tears the paper backing. Nothing. Now, smash to--

dialogues.speaker: FELT IN A SWEAT, BOLTING INTO THE HOUSE. 119
dialogues.text: Now running his fingers along the edges and corners of everything. We’re in his house. He’s peering behind his posters ... u his desk ... aims a flashlight in the heating grates. Audrey following him from room to room. He unscrews the mouthpiece of the kitchen phone. She’s standing, watching

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Do they know?!

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Do they know what--? What?? What do you think they know? What is there to know? (explodes at her) Can you for once in your life just shut up, Audrey!! Just shut the hell up! And as Audrey freezes, Felt runs. WE FOLLOW HIM to the ba edging the pool, toward the pitch dark of the woods behin right to the edge of it. Defiance. It’s him against the infinite black wall of night.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C'mon! Here I am! ... C’MON!  120 121 91. INT. GRAY’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 120 Felt and Miller. Felt back to his composed imperious self

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I asked Mr. Miller to join us as a witness. (heavy silence; then) This is my fault. It is me. Miller and Gray stare at him, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: (confused) Mark, what are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Everything that happens inside this building is my responsibility. If there is a rat, if the White House has someone inside the Bureau, I should know. So it’s on me. (and so) I want your permission to do a full internal investigation. I’1l bring down an inspection team from New York. I want everyone who’s been in contact with the Watergate files polygraphed. I’1l run it myself.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: (and throws a glance at Miller) They’11 hate you for it.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Everything is on the line. We're running out of time. (and cut to--) ANGIE LANO’S FACE FILLING THE SCREEN, STUCK IN A SNEER. 1 PULL BACK TO REVEAL an interrogation room. Lano’s hooked to a polygraph machine, answering a POLYGRAPHER’S questio

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH A ONE-WAY MIRROR
dialogues.text: Is an observation room. Felt watches with Miller.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How many is that?  122 92.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Fifteen total. Mr. Lano’s the last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we don't have a thing. (troubled) Has the FBI ever done this to its own?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I want Mr. Lano to sign a sworn affidavit that he has not passed information to Woodward or Bernstein or any other reporter. I want everyone in the Washington Field Office to sign one. Miller looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: You're humiliating them. Through the glass Lano is RIPPING off the wires and electrodes. The Polygrapher steps out.

dialogues.speaker: POLYGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Okay are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: POLYGRAPHER
dialogues.text: The polygraph.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: POLYGRAPHER
dialogues.text: His own orders. No exceptions. Lano has stepped out.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: I‘1l tell you one thing. It’1l make all this go down easier for the rest of us. Lano glares. Felt imperious, opaque. A long pause. Felt’s cornered. Nowhere to look. Turns right into it. To Miller

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (the bluff) Do it, Mr. Miller. Set it up. INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HO - DAY 122 Felt at his desk.  93.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL/ INTERCOM
dialogues.text: Mr. Dean at the White House.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (picks up) Mr. Dean.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/ PHONE
dialogues.text: Pat Gray was quite taken by the way you've taken charge. He said you insisted on having yourself polygraphed but your own men wouldn’t allow it. (then) Lucky for you, I guess. Beat. Then they both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/PHONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing like this in the history of the FBI, I understand. They both wait for the other to blink. Felt can wait all

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/PHONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have it yet.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Progress is slow. Pause. Tense silence.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN/ PHONE
dialogues.text: This must be very uncomfortable for you. (and holding on Felt--)

dialogues.speaker: CROWD, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: FOUR MORE YEARS! FOUR MORE It was a great victory, but YEARS the greater the victory, the greater the responsibility, the greater the opportunity! The applause CRESCENDOING as we cut to-- NIXON ON TV SPEECHIFYING THROUGH A CONFETTI RAIN.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON/TV
dialogues.text: ...dedicating ourselves to those great goals that I have discussed at such great length throughout this campaign-- (and now)  123
INT. DEN - FELT’S HOME - NIGHT 123 Felt and Audrey watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER CRONKITE/TV, (OVER)
dialogues.text: (broadcast) With a more than 22% margin of victory, some are referring to this as the greatest victory in American political history. Felt rises, shuts it off. He leaves the room. We follow him through the house room room. To the phone. He picks it up but doesn’t dial. He j listens a long beat. Puts it down. Crosses to the window peers out. STREET - an FBI car sits out front. Two Agents watching t house. We HOLD on this, suddenly not knowing - as Felt suddenly doesn’t know - who those agents really are. The phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (picks up; into phone) Hello? (silence) Hello? (nothing) Hello? O.S. a door slams. Audrey has gone upstairs. Felt is star at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Is someone there? Now we HEAR WHAT HE HEARS: (OVER) A PATTERN OF CLICKS AND HISSES. Felt hangs up. TAP TAP. Felt whirls. Jumpy. It's a tree. Scraping the glass. Nothing. Back to the window, peers through the curtains. The street is empty.  124 125 95. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: AND UP TO
dialogues.text: 124 Felt’s Buick joins the traffic past the Capitol, whirlpoo past the Lincoln Memorial. The car STOPS past a bus stop along the Potomac. Felt par exits, and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt sits beside a MAN in a trench and hat.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: The knives are out.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: More than you know.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Am I safe?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: No one is. You’re being watched. The White House is going to sanitize the entire town. (then) The Director of Central Intelligence will be gone by morning.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Why.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Apparently, he couldn’t smoke you out fast enough. (Felt looks at him, but says nothing) The source. Of those stories. After a pause.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Where does the CIA stand? 125  126 96.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: The CIA is building a wall. We’1l stay out of your way, but if we are forced to protect ourselves we will. (then) The FBI will never reach the CIA on this.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: And the White House?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: The CIA’s position is, Presidents come and go. The CIA stays. The FBI stays. We are the constants. Felt up, about to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Almost forgot. Time Magazine's Person of the Year is going to be Richard Nixon. Thought you’d like to know. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Holidays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNDER Lawrence Welk’s Christmas Carol schmaltz: a Norman Rockwellian gingerbread happiness. A dozen stockings a- hanging. Crackling fire in the hearth. A Christmas tree afloat on a sea of unwrapped toys. PAN ACROSS the table: Felt and Audrey, Ed and Pat Miller. Miller’s THREE YOUNG CHILDREN. All before their perfect, shiny Christmas dinner. Felt, the patriarch, carves the perfect turkey. Now Felt is playing with Miller’s littlest girl. On his b giving her a plane ride. The girl screeching with delight AUDREY standing in the kitchen doorway, watching. Drinkin

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Mark! (lost in the laughter) Do you do that on purpose?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What? C’mon, we’re just having fun. Audrey starts to cry. Pat Miller goes to Audrey.  97.

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER
dialogues.text: Honey. What are we doing wrong?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: He’s always playing his games.

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER
dialogues.text: What games, honey?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: He knows-- (and now Ed Miller) You know.

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER
dialogues.text: Honey we all care so much.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You blame me, all of you! He does! (Felt; not explodes) What do you all want from me! To laugh and sing? !

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Do you think you’re the only one in pain?! Can’t you see anything except how it affects you?!

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No! I can’t! It’s just maybe I’ma little more honest about it-- (an awkward quiet, and Pat pulls her into the foyer, the two women) Don’t you dare say anything until you know what it’s like to come home and one of those children is just gone. Because it’1ll happen to you, too--!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat, stung, leans in anyway. Eyes moist. Stoic.

dialogues.speaker: PAT MILLER
dialogues.text: It’s easy to be great when they’re babies, isn’t it. Then they become people, and you have to deal with them. Just like everyone else. (and as she goes out--) 127 INT. JOAN’S ROOM - FELT HOME - NIGHT 127

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt stands in the middle of the room. The room is EMPTY, CLEANED OUT, all signs of human life ERASED. HOLD ... The  128 129 130 131 132

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128 THE WATERGATE BURGLARS filing into a Washington DC courtr taking the oath...

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR, (OVER)
dialogues.text: As the trial of the five men accused of breaking into the Watergate Hotel continues, alleged ringleader G. Gordon Liddy pled guilty to six felony counts. HOWARD HUNT giving a press conference...

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD HUNT
dialogues.text: No higher-ups were involved in the break-in. THE BURGLARS now standing at a news conference podium.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Claiming no connection whatsoever to the White House, the Watergate burglars changed their minds and pled guilty to all eight counts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A limo idles at the curb, in a swirl of snow. The door to Felt’s home opens. Felt crosses shrugging on a coat, and-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt slides in next to Gray.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: The President told me the unthinkable has happened: he actually misses Hoover. Hoover would have gotten the dogs off him, he said. He’d have everyone scared to death. Felt staring out the window. Into a fresh snowfall.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The White House is going to make me Director permanently.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Congratulations. 129 130 131 132  133 134 99.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Bill Sullivan will be my Number Two. (and waits for Felt’s reaction) That sits there. Long enough for the ramifications to str both men. Felt doesn’t so much as blink. Then--

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what the President said to me today? He said, ‘The Germans had the right idea during World War II. If they went through a town and one of their soldiers got hit by a sniper, they'd line up the whole goddamn town and kill everyone’. He said it’s time to clean out the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You know what that will mean for me.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Remember, they’re afraid of you. The President said you know everything there is to know in the FBI. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark. If you did know something, you could come to me. We’d be able to work it out together. We could do something about it. Nothing. Pause. Felt starts to get out--

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t protect you any more. Just give them what they want. The traitor’s head on a platter. (and then we find--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt watches the limo’s taillights recede, then to-- INT. JOAN’S ROOM - FELT HOME 134 Felt entering. Audrey close behind. Looking for a place t alone. Enters here. The one room he knows Audrey won’t en Closing the door on her.  135

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Mark? (stares at the wood, and now INTERCUT) FELT ON THE OTHER SIDE. Their foreheads connected by wood

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you did it to save us from those lunatics. Felt squeezes his eyes. She feels him there, reached for where his head would be. Then turns. Back against the doo Guarding him. Then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt on his way up alone. Doors open. A half-dozen agents step on. Sullivan among them.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What brings you back?

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Two words. Re-venge. Sullivan pushes out. The doors close. And we find Felt in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. HOOVER’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY A136 His and our first time in since he claimed the throne as Now, it is lost. As he stands there before all he has fai we cut to-- Carol waiting for him outside. Until she can’t wait any m

dialogues.speaker: CAROL TSCHUDY
dialogues.text: Mr. Felt. Mr. Miller is on the phone. (now cut to--) INT. /EXT. FELT’S CAR/FBI GARAGE - THAT DAY 136

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt emerges from the elevator, crossing toward his parke car. Loitering around is Miller and an UNDERCOVER AGENT, plainclothes in his 20's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt passes them without so much as a nod, simply gets in car, and waits. Miller nods at the agent. They both get i with Felt. Miller up front, the agent behind.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER FELT
dialogues.text: This is Special Agent Clarke-- I don’t want to know his name.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Tell him what you told Mr. Bates and me. Agent nervous. Felt’s imperious eyes in the rear view mir study him.  101.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: I don’t think you have anything to worry about, Mr. Felt.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: You don’t think?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Specific.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: The commune where the subject, Joan Felt, is--

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Do not say her name--

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Copy. Where the target is. Definitely some people of interest in there. Maybe some Weather Underground--

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: But the -- target? Felt’s eyes. Desperate now, almost pleading:

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: If you ask me, just someone’s kid looking for a way home. (and as we PUSH IN on Felt) To a stranger he gives nothing. But in TIGHTER: his eyes moisten. To us, he’s holding back a flood of relief and agony. As Felt nods--

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: We never spoke. No paper. You don’t know anything. Get out now. (and as the Agent goes, withdraws into the shadow of the garage) Felt and Miller sit in a long silence. Both men looking ahead. Until Felt, barely a whisper--

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Thank you. Miller pats Felt’s hand on the wheel. Holds a beat. The t men. The two fathers. Then leaves him.  137 102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt waits in a booth. The booth we saw him staring into earlier. A violent storm rattles the window. Eyes SCANNING every face. Everyone a suspect. HIS POV lan on hands, expressions, mouths. Eyes seem to come back to His steely glare chases them away. In slides Smith. Shaking the wet off.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Bill Sullivan is picking out colors for his new office. He’s going to turn the FBI into the KGB.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: So it’s over. (waitress wanders by)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Bring coffee (then, to Smith) Get out your notebook. (then) May 1969. And February 1971--

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Mark. (stopping him - yes?) Are you sure about this? (he’s very fucking sure of this, because--)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Between those dates White House employees were wiretapped, many of them aides to the Secretary of State. And five reporters. Including the New York Times.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You're kidding. (but Felt’s not kidding)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Some of the names of the targets came down from Henry Kissinger. Pause. Smith looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: This is hard for you.  103.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What part?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: All this truth. Truth is hard for you. (but now that he’s started Felt wants to just keep going)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: The targets went from Kissinger to the FBI. And the FBI illegally, unconstitutionally, and reprehensibly bugged and taped and secretly photographed and memorialized every move those people made. Them and their wives and their mistresses and homosexual lovers.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Who did the wiretaps, Mark?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Bill Sullivan. (which now makes perfect fucking sense) It became a rogue FBI operation. Sullivan drove it. Sullivan and the White House. By themselves.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: What about you? (what about me?) What did you know?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: About everything else I knew every sordid little detail. But not this. They knew they couldn’t tell me about this.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: They couldn’t count on you.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: This is when the darkness started to creep in. This is when the rot started to happen. (and a long pause now, the Big Truth coming) The White House is packing all its crimes in separate little boxes ... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Watergate, the spying, the ugliness, the rot. Each thing in a different box so no one can put it together, so no one sees it’s all connected ... and no one will care. But it’s all the same big thing. Smith stares. Humbled by all this truth himself now, so--

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Watergate is just the gateway. Smith puts down a fork. Or a cup.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Do you know physics, Sandy? If you tap repeatedly on the post of a building, and the beating is relentless, it creates a rhythm, a resonance- (Felt starts to tap the table, slowly, repeatedly «+. tap ... tap ... tap) If you do that long enough, and steadily enough, it will feed-back, the frequencies will align ... the molecules will scramble ... and the whole thing - the whole building - will come apart from the inside and collapse in on itself. And all come tumbling down. (beat) The molecules are beginning to scramble. The FBI is coming apart. You know where that takes us? You want a country this big, this angry, this confused, without a police department? (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes we have to betray the thing we love, to save the thing we love. Which triggers a momentary collapse in Felt. A slow eye- blink. He pats his own head. Then as quickly, embarrassed

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: This - what you’re doing - will bring down the whole house of cards. The President’s surveillance mania. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then you already knew that.  138 139 105.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (tired) The White House is a syndicate, Sandy. It’s a criminal organization. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you get out the story before Gray’s confirmation hearing?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: One week. (and Felt gets up, and--)

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Felt and Gray in back. Along with two of Gray’s flacks. G pouring over a legal pad of notes. Felt stares out the window as the Capitol comes into view

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Any last-minute advice?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: We've gone over everything. They’11l go easy; you’re the President's man. GRAY’S FLACK What about this? And pulls out the Smith TIME Magazine story. WE PUSH IN o the lead header: “Secret Wiretapping by the FBI”.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what my position should be.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: It was before your time. Tell the truth. No one can argue with the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray is perspiring. It’s going badly. He’s like a boxer i the 8th round taking a serious beating.  106. Arrayed before him, seven U.S. SENATORS, a dozen PHOTOGRAPHERS, 100 SPECTATORS at his back. CAMERA FINDS F in the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR 1
dialogues.text: (irate; a Woodward/Wash Post clipping in his hands ) And what about the assertion in this article that a White House aide slipped Donald Segretti, a target of the Bureau’s Watergate investigation, copies of what the FBI had?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: (unsteady ) Uh, we didn’t look into that.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR 1
dialogues.text: Why on earth not?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I’1l have to look into that.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR 1
dialogues.text: Did you know the White House had your confidential files?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray looks to Felt. Felt glances away

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I did, yes, Senator. (and pauses, unfocused; desperately wanting to please) Um, let me tell you how it might have happened.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR 1
dialogues.text: Please do. (and as we continue, we quickly see--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray and Dean sitting side by side on a bench. Gray carri briefcase, Dean a big envelope. As we’re hearing--  107.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (OVER)
dialogues.text: White House counsel John Dean told me the White House wanted everything the FBI had on Watergate. To help with its own investigation. (should stop talking, but) It was the President’s wish. So Mr. Dean took all those FBI files Gray puts the briefcase on the ground. Dean opens. Looks through the contents, closes it again. Now back to

dialogues.speaker: THE HEARING
dialogues.text: Close on FELT as--

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR 1
dialogues.text: I’m confused. How did Mr. Dean, a potential target of the investigation, come to possess FBI files about that investigation?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Because I gave them to him. Something big is happening. The room can feel it.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR 1
dialogues.text: (grave) How many Bureau reports are we talking about? How many reports did you give Mr. Dean?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I believe it was eighty-two.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR 1
dialogues.text: As Acting Director of the FBI, why on earth would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Because I was told to.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR 1
dialogues.text: By who?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: The President. That's it. The room ERUPTS. But we’re holding on Felt.  141 108.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR 2
dialogues.text: So, if I have this right, Mr. Dean purposely mis-led the FBI. Lied to them?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: (before he thinks--) I would have to conclude that probably is correct, yes sir. The room is electric. As we start to intercut with--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen stockings dangle over a fireplace. Gray - in card with reindeers - approaching with an armful of wrapping paper. Tosses it all onto the fire, now contemplating the flames, as we go back to--

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I do understand, though, that the materials you’re talking about were kept in a safe in the White House.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR 2
dialogues.text: And how would you know that?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I know because Mr. Dean gave those and other files to me. (and now back to--) THE CABIN. Where Gray is left standing at the fire cradli small stack of files stamped “TOP SECRET. EYES ONLY.” And starts to read. Then wishes he hadn't. And now simply throws all that into the flames, and now s back to--

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He told me they should never see the light of day. He told me to ‘deep six’ the files. To destroy them. (and then) I burned them at my vacation home.  142 143 There it is. Like a bomb going off, the room explodes. Fe who set this up all along - is the one still point in the room. EXT. WASHINGTON D.C. - MORNING - FELT’S BUICK Crossing the Potomac.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: As we follow it past the Capitol, the White House, and in the FBI HQ--

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Today, in one of the most difficult decisions of my presidency, I accepted the resignations of two of my closest associates in the White House -- John Ehrlichman, Bob Haldeman -- two of the finest public servants it has been my privilege to know. The counsel to the president, John Dean, has also resigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt approaches the elevator doors. WE HEAR footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So the President asks me what he should do-- (Felt slows, feels Sullivan behind him) And I tell him to get rid of everyone. In the interests of the nation. I didn't mean me, of course. Felt has reached the elevator. He presses the button. SULLIVAN (CONT’D) You don't have many friends left, you know. A bunch of your FBI pals told me I should cut your nuts off. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gonna let you keep your badge? (Felt turns now, imperious) You got a lotta people Washington worried. They think you're going to come out and unwrap everything. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 142 143  144 110. SULLIVAN (CONT’D) Everything from all the years. Everything we [you and I] know. (as Felt steps into the elevator)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Is that what you want to know, Bill? This your last little errand? To help everyone sleep at night?

dialogues.speaker: SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Just saying. You open those scabs, there’s a lot of things underneath. Doors finally open. And as Felt steps in, and doors close SULLIVAN (CONT’D) Just remember. No one likes informers. They only remember you as a rat. Even if you were their rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt enters. Puts down his briefcase. Hangs up his hat an coat. Crosses to Audrey at the table. A day like any othe Felt sits in front of a tall Manhattan. Pulls at the drin He takes out his list of California commune addresses now spreads it out on the table between them. That one addres circled now: “Genesis Commune, Ben Lomand."

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I found her. (she goes still; a long beat; disbelief--)

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You found her. Alive? Is she in trouble? Felt eyes moisten, grateful. He shakes his head, No.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long have you known?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: A week.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: A week? Mark?? You can play games with all of them-- (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (points outside) But-- (she starts to cry) I’m her mother.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: It wasn’t safe.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: For who? Beat. Audrey’s silent.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Let’s just go get our baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty hills, wild flowers, azure sky. lll. 145 TWO YOUNG BEAUTIFUL WOMEN sit in a field, completely nake nursing INFANTS, sharing a joint. We know one from

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Hey look. pictures. A cloud of dust on the horizon. Then a car snaking over t intermeshed hills. A government sedan. We make out a MAN the wheel, a female PASSENGER.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh my god. (slowly to her feet) It’s my parents.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Anti-Christ? Really?! (squints) How can you tell?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Just promise me you’1l remember. No matter what: our bodies are beautiful. (and) And don’t fall in love with him. All my friends fall in love with him. Joan defiant. They half-dress. Car stops. Felt and out. He in his FBI suit. She with white gloves and pill b hat. Audrey get  112.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: That’s your dad?? He’s gorgeous! Felt can’t get to Joan fast enough. Walking first. Then h runs. And without a word or permission he just wraps her the baby in his arms, just like that. And starts to cry. by the sheer force of his love Joan relents and collapses into him, just like that. Audrey holds onto the car door, paralyzed. WIDE & LONG - THREE HIPPIE MEN jogging out from the commu

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Felt takes off his jacket, trades it for the baby. Felt l the baby to the sky, laughing. They turn and walk to Audrey. Felt holds the baby out to Audrey stares at the child. Hands pinned to her sides.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Mark?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: This is your grandson. Felt presses the baby to Audrey’s breast, takes one of he arms and wraps it around the child.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Audrey, this is Ludi.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You sent the FBI after me? (Felt, smiling, shakes, No) Then how did you find me? And Felt takes out one of the envelopes he’s been address

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: One didn’t come back. Felt opens his arms and pulls both his women into him. Th two women collapsing against each other.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatever happened, whatever I did, whatever we did - or didn’t do - I’m sorry - we’re sorry. We need you. Your mother and I need you now.  146 113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt strolling, contemplative, alone, among the shelters playing kids. Jacket over his shoulder. Shoulder holster visible but empty. While-- Audrey on a bench. Holding Ludi. With her gloves and pill hat. Joan beside her. She’s a little drunk. Joan knows. Joan looks at her a lit sadly, then at Felt--

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I had this feeling when I was little, that I couldn’t see into his eyes. That he didn’t approve of me. He was always holding me up to some impossible standard.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: That was me. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you were sick, and you were little, it was your father who climbed into bed with you. In his shoes. His holster. His suit. He’d sit with you for hours and rock you til you fell asleep again. Joan looks at Felt. As if to ask, what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I used to dress you up. Remember how you used to come downstairs and show off your new clothes? (Felt--) He adored you. He thought you could be the first female President-- (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted you to be [like me][a movie star]. They both watch Felt stroll. Joan touches her mother’s kn Connection. And pity.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He talks to me. You know how he is. I’m the only one he can really talk to. (and then--)  147 148 114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan gets out of a VW van with DOUGLAS GILLIES: pony tail beard. 27 but looks 18. Joan leads him toward a converted chicken coop, long and low. Stops at the door. Gillies hesitates, then-- INT. JOAN’S BUNK - GENESIS COMMUNE - SAME 148

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan and Gillies enter to find Felt sitting in the miniat room, an empty chair across from him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Daddy, this is my friend. He’s a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: GILLIES
dialogues.text: Douglas Gillies. (and as Felt takes him in)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: When did you graduate from law school?

dialogues.speaker: GILLIES
dialogues.text: Ten months ago. Felt sighs, stands - has to stoop - shakes Gillies’ hand. GILLIES (CONT’D) Look, I didn’t want to come. You stand for everything I despise. I came because I admire your daughter, and she asked me. (and Felt, as if he simply chose not to hear that, says--)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Have a seat. (when he’s down) I need to consult an attorney. (and hands him a dollar) I am now protected by attorney- client privilege. Whatever I say to you, you can never tell a living soul without my permission.

dialogues.speaker: GILLIES
dialogues.text: I know that. But why me? Felt looks at Gillies. His strong, almost Job-like presen Felt shifts in his chair, more and more uncomfortable.  115.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Because you are now - as my lawyer - the only person in America I can trust. (and doesn’t quite know how to react to that strange and terrible irony) I’ve been in the FBI Longer than you've been alive. I live according to a code. There are things an FBI man does and doesn’t do. It’s black and white. (rambling) But there’s loyalty. And then there’s duty. There are things bigger than ourselves. Can you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: GILLIES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’ve done something - things - that cannot be undone. But I want to know what I’ve done. (and looks up at him) Am I the man I think I am? Pause. Gillies takes in this man in obvious pain.

dialogues.speaker: GILLIES
dialogues.text: You want to know about your soul. (--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know who is going to forgive you. Felt looks through the slats in the barn wall. Catches fragments of Audrey quietly coming close, trying to hear.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: (realizing) I don’t need a lawyer. I need a priest. And now we begin to HEAR in PRE-LAP:

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: I have never been a quitter. To leave office before my term is completed is abhorrent to every instinct in my body. (and cut to)  149 150 116.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt in the doorway of Joan’s coop, watching Gillies’ van disappear over the hills. His expression relaxed, unburde

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: But as President, I must put the interest of America first. (continuing over) Joan stepping into Felt, and Felt puts his arm around her NIXON (OVER) (CONT’D) Therefore, I shall resign the Presidency effective at noon tomorrow. (continuing as we go to--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt’s retirement party, subdued and sparsely attended.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Vice President Ford will be sworn in as President at that hour in this office. (continuing over--) Felt shaking lots of hands, smiling with grace. No one ma eye contact. Now cut to- Audrey sits in the corner by herself. Then-- NIXON (OVER) (CONT’D) But as President, I must put the interest of America first. Felt is presented with a plaque, a watch. Now Felt and new DIRECTOR posing for the requisite hand-s wall photo. FLASH! And HOLD. Then to black, and, over bla

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: I would say only that if some of my judgments were wrong, and some were wrong, they were made in what I believed at the time to be the best interest of the Nation. (and up to--)  151 152 117. INT. LIVING ROOM, FELT’S HOME - DAY 151 Felt facing the TV. Casual slacks, slippers. Dinner and a high-ball on the TV tray.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: On the tube is Nixon. Audrey comes up behind Felt, hands on his shoulders. And Nixon talks, Audrey holds onto him, forehead against his back, as though to keep him from floating away. HOLD, the cut to-- O.S. LOUD DOOR KNOCK. Felt crosses to the door and opens Angie Lano. Matches Felt’s imperiousness with his own.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Mr. Lano.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: Mr. Felt. (and then--)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt - now in a suit - follows Lano across the lawn to a waiting car.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: What’s this really about? Lano cocks his head at the irony of the moment.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: You tell me. You were the boss.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’ll take my car.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: Why don’t you ride with me. (and Felt looks at Lano’s car)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’m not getting in there with you.

dialogues.speaker: LANO
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be here if you had a choice. Audrey appears in the doorway.  118.

dialogues.speaker: LANO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l have him back in a couple hours.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You have no idea what you're doing! (she doesn’t appreciate the irony of the moment, but Felt does--)

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: Sure he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond a rope barrier - ‘Restricted - Grand Jury and Witnesses Only’ - the hallway is populated by nervous FBI AGENTS and their LAWYERS. It’s quiet and tense. Felt approaches, marching down the hall. Charlie Bates, nervously smoking, intercepts.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: What are you doing? You shouldn't be here.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: They're charging you? (and as Bates says nothing) Get out of my way, Mr. Bates. Felt marches for three FEDERAL PROSECUTORS huddling outsi the courtroom. All hungry Top Guns in their early 30's.

dialogues.speaker: FELT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Which one’s Pottinger? STAN POTTINGER, 33, hip-smart New Yorker turns.

dialogues.speaker: POTTINGER
dialogues.text: Jesus, look who’s here. Mark Felt. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’m going to testify.

dialogues.speaker: POTTINGER
dialogues.text: We didn’t subpoena you.  119.

dialogues.speaker: FELT
dialogues.text: I’m aware of that. (looks over at Bates and a few others) They were following orders. Why don’t you go after the guy who was giving them?

dialogues.speaker: GARDNER
